There is one other character of note and that is Rimuru's "chosen" one by the name of Shizue Izawa voiced bu Yumiri Hanamori, another person summoned into this world, but forced through a demon pact, Rimuru befriends her and later on passes her legacy onto Rimuru, giving Rimuru more motivation and something to strive for in this world than his own and two great things comes from entire ordeal.


One and the most obvious one being that Rimuru grows through his friendships and allies especially with Shizue as she was extremely important to Rimuru's growth as a character throughout the anime because of it and this extends onto any new ally he faces even if they are at first deterred by Rimuru, he let bygones by bygones and makes their place in Rimuru's flourishing village grow that much more as a result.


The second and the more obvious one is that Shizue's inclusion added ALOT of world building to Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken's world, what does LA mean by that?, well though the anime mostly resides in the goblin village at first, Rimuru explores his new world, makes trade deals, recruits blacksmiths, architects, magic users to grow not only his village but the world building itself, like a two for one deal and how they implemented this was actually ingeniously done. Coming from an isekai, the main focus for the most part, the bland main male protagonist, Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken manages to work it's world building and it's character development all in one just by simply befriending them.


Now the other part of the world building comes in with Shizue and how she was summoned into the world, which brings up new lore as the world Rimuru is in now are also inhabited by humans from his previous world, like this is a normal occurrence. Lastly would be the villains themselves and this ties it in as a demon summoned Shizue and one of Shizue's motivations was to find her master, now passed onto Rimuru wants to find Shizue's master, but it's not easy when the demons are one, powerful and two, send in monsters or plan up something that threatens Rimuru's village and his allies' territories.


If Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken was telling of a theme, it's showing the positive, befriending nature of Rimuru that is at the core of Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken and sure it took time for this theme to be fleshed out in the anime but it was pretty solid by the end of the anime even with all the demon scheming and other important character backstories were going on at the time.


With all that being said, LA's favourite characters form the anime (and there are ALOT of character to be honest) are, Millim Nava voiced by Rina Hidaka as a hyper genki and powerful demon lord but fancies Rimuru also she had some great comedic moments at that (though LA thought she was a filler only character for some reason but no she's canon!), Shino voiced by M.A.O an oni who is Rimuru's secretary and has an obvious crush on Rimuru and finally Gobuta voiced by Asuna Tomari, a pipsqueak of a goblin but has some crazy latent luck or he was naturally powerful (an obvious but good gag for this character and comes to a direct comparison to Rimuru in a ways of looking weak but is waay more powerful than they look) and Shizue gets a mention for being a pinnacle part of the anime and the turning point of when the anime got REALLY good.


8Bit who did the animation actually did an amazing job with the animation, from the exotic character designs and some impressive battle animation. The character designs are just by default exotic with the variety of species Rimuru take sin and sometimes some changes to them with Rimuru's magic and whatnot and LA is some fo the few that actually liked the oni's change to be more human-like features. The battle animation was greatly done with each attack done with great impact helped by the sound direction and background work. 8Bit outdid themselves with the animation to be totally honest here though 8Bit had always had potential from their other anime works, this was just showing what they could really do and maybe more.


Voice cast, well due to the large cast, LA will go with only the most notable ones, Miho Okusaki as Rimuru was great with an amazing range of cadence and really gave life to Rimuru and his likable personality, Rina Hidaka of course gets a mention as the destructive genki Millim, Yumiri Hanamori as Shizue was awesome, M.A.O and Sayaka Senbongi as Shion and Shuna was rather well done even as a pigeonholed role from both but still. Great cast what else?


LA will say that Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken isn't without flaws, LA already mentioned the first few episodes were rushed and cliched of an isekai but there is another one and that is as much as LA LOVES the world building in this anime, Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken does tend to exposition ALOT using the Grand Sage voiced by Megumi Toyoguchi, but man there were episodes where it was exposition and not much else, yes it helps us the audience gets us in the know as well as setup and build up for the upcoming episodes but it did kill the pacing...."rarely" though.


Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken is one of those shows you just can't judge on the first episode, you NEED to watch the entire thing and your judgment and feelings towards this anime will change, it did for LA as LA thought LA was gonna see the typical overpowered harem isekai anime scthick all over again, but nope, we get a one part Rimuru wrecks a monstrosity that the demons made, one part wholesome anime about a slime who befriends and grows a NATION of monsters filled with character development from even some minor characters and great amount of world building to make this world both have that nostalgic RPG feel but also make the world alive and realized at the same time, yes the anime does get exposition heavy at times but that does not detract from what Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken has and had going for it and with it already announcing a second season, there is ALOT more potential that Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken can go and LA will be interested where it'll go in it's second season. Color LA surprised by this isekai installment. 


Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken maybe on normal mode, but man LA didn't think making a Civilization anime adaptation with a slime could be this much fun!

tensei shitara slime datta ken is just a generic isekai anime like others.
just a guy transported to a fantasy world but as a slime.
despite the common concept of a story that they use, its still enjoyable. when i say enjoyable, i mean really enjoyable. to be honest, i cant stop watching this anime and i even read the manga and the web novel and with that i can say that this series is a walking masterpiece.
i know saying this anime as a masterpiece is just a stupid idea but in my opinion, i found this series very very interesting. just the idea of starting anew life and then leading a small village to the point where they establish a whole country is just amazing. it makes you really appreciate rimuru's hardwork and want to know more and more.\n\n
to be honest, words cant describe how much i love this series and knowing that i need to wait a year for another season is a bit hard for me. well in the meantime, reading ahead in the manga and web novel is always a good idea.\n\n
to show my love to this series, i have put everything to 10. well alot of people will probably disagree with me but thats what ratings for right ?

‘That Time I Got Reincarnated As A Slime’ is simply put just an average isekai show - with nothing special to offer. Now don’t get me wrong, it wasn’t terrible, in fact I did enjoy moments throughout the show but in the end it didn’t really leave an impact on me nor did I enjoy it all too well overall.
The main plot revolves around Rimuru: a middle-aged neet who ends up dying and in turn is given a ‘second chance’ at life in another world as a slime - a common trope within isekai shows. At the beginning of the show, Rimuru easily adapts tohis surroundings and his form as being a slime - he learns of his abilities and what is needed for him to grow stronger. His character is refreshing: he’s a powerful & a strong slime who helps people with the power he gains & proves all those who doubt his strength wrong - it’s fun and enticing for the audience. But, within the first arc or so his character started to become boring, everything started to become repetitive: his actions, dialogue, reactions etc. and it seemed like no actual character development happened throughout, he’s the same slime as he was at the beginning stages of the show, it seemed like none of the events had affected him or built him up as a character in any way really. That’s not necessarily a problem but it in turn makes Rimuru kind of boring to watch which affects the overall story - I mean he is the main character after all. Now, throughout the story we’re introduced to several side characters: the goblins, Shizue, Verudora and so on; the side characters within the show, in all honesty, don’t really add much to the story for me. They all fit the basic archetypes (e.g Millim, a half-naked loli who, of course, is 500+ years old & is a dragon) that we tend to see in most isekais’ - it’s nothing new. The fact that I cared more for a dragon that appeared in literally one episode compared to any of the other characters is kinda sad honestly; a character I actually liked within the show, Shizue, was introduced and somehow ended up as an ‘important’ character for Rimuru’s ‘development’ despite not appearing for all that long, maybe I just misinterpreted things but I honestly don’t see how she became an important character. It felt really forced like they just needed a character that’ll be Rimuru’s driving support & someone he thinks about for motivation or whatever - I liked her character so in my opinion it’s kind of a waste to only see her for a while - I feel like they could’ve done a lot more with her.


In terms of animation, it was average: the settings and character design wasn’t anything too special and it wasn’t really all too aesthetically pleasing but the action scenes flowed well visually and in turn made it more exciting and thrilling. The animation isn’t something that is anything bad nor do I think it affected the show - it’s the story & characters that I have problems with.


The plot, to me, was an utter mess: some episodes had almost no progression while others just threw everything into your face leaving you unsatisfied and disappointed - especially some of the action episodes e.g episode 19. I enjoyed the beginning arc along with the orc arc but after that I became disinterested - I’m just not a fan of messy progression. I do understand the show revolves around action and therefore requires a few episodes of ‘down-time’ before picking up the pace again but in all honesty it wasn’t well executed: each slower episode of info-dumping felt more like fillers rather than setting up for what's to come while the action episodes started to become more and more repetitive. After a while the episodes just left a bad taste in my mouth.


The sound design & sound track weren’t anything all too special. I’m not a big fan of the OP or the ED - I do think they’re good songs and compliment the show well, but they’re just not for me - and none of the OST really stood out to me at all. I’m not an expert in sound design so I’m not going to really comment on it.


Overall, it was an OK experience - nothing more than average. It had fun moments but also messier moments too (which, for me, seemed to outweigh the good moments) and, to add to that, I wasn’t the biggest fan of any of the characters. It left me feeling unsatisfied and I just ended up feeling disappointed with the show - after all it has a lot of hype surrounding it and at the beginning it was an interesting concept. Would I recommend it? If you’re an isekai fan go ahead and watch it: I feel like fans of isekai will enjoy this show a lot more than I did. But if you’re not a fan of isekai, I don’t really suggest this show as an ‘ultimate go-to must watch’, I think it’s a show that you can avoid and you won’t really be missing much by doing so.


My score: 6/10


(to emphasise, since I know there are plentiful fans of this show: this is purely my opinion - feel free to disagree).

I'm going to be honest, the more I watched this show, the less I liked it. It definitely had me at the start; I liked the concept of an Isekai where the MC basically just nice guys his way to having his own kingdom, and the brisk pace made the show relatively easy to watch, but the father along I got into this show, more and more problems popped up that were too much of a distraction for me to really enjoy "That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime" as a whole. 
Story is a 6 for me, and I think i'm being prettygenerous here if i'm going to be honest. The story is split into multiple separate arcs (which i'm guessing make up each of the various light novels) in which our protagonist Rimuru Tempest experiences troubles while adjusting to this new world he's been transported to. Like I said earlier, the pace is extremely quick, so by the time we get to the 4th episode, Rimuru has already become the leader of a village of goblins. I can see why so many people would get hooked by these early episodes, as a kind of turn your brain off easy to watch junk food anime. I actually had been enjoying it myself, and if the show had kept to this level during the duration of this show's airtime, but by the score i'm giving here it's pretty obvious that at least to me, it didn't. 


Halfway through the first cour, Rimuru meets another person who had been isekai'd into that world named Shizue Izawa, and for some reason, everything that had been previously going on just got dropped to focus on her, but only for two episodes for some reason. Rimuru apparently had been seing her in his dreams and thought they were "destined to be together" or something, but he literally knows nothing about her, until finding out her backstory via an episode long exposition dump, in which she subsequently dies. I seriously did not know what to take of this, with Rimuru for some reason absorbing her body being surrounded by characters we had just met and didn't know anything about crying like this was supposed to be some important landmark event. This event seriously dampened my excitement for the show, and it never really went back up to where it was before; with storylines being dropped just as quickly as they are picked up, resulting in a deflated, boring, power-creeping plot that has no clear path. This can be seen most clearly with the fight with the Charybdis, in which this monster, who was described as being able to destroy kingdoms, gets killed in one hit one episode after it had been brought up. This is when fast pacing becomes a detriment, not a positive.


Don't know where to add this, but I forgot to mention just how jarring the ending was. 16 minutes into the 25th episode, with Rimuru heading back to his town of Rimuru(lol) after being gone for like 5 episodes, the song for the 1st OP begins playing and the rest of the episode just becomes a recap of what had happened so far. I was audibly shocked by this, and I couldn't stop laughing for a few minutes after this had happened.


Art i'm giving a 7. The character designs are inoffensive enough, if a bit crazily sexualized, Rimuru is cute enough as an amorphous blob, and the background art is just the same bland characterless background art that's seen in every fantasy anime nowadays, but hey, at least they didn't use CG. The animation can be pretty good during action scenes, but the character animation is nothing to really write home about, and there are no scenes in particular that i'd really credit as "amazingly animated" , so overall it's just good but really nothing else-- well at least aside from the openings. those were pretty nice.


Sound: I'm going to be honest, I don't remember any of the songs from this show. That's a bit of a shock for me, because I tend to pay a lot of attention to anime OSTs, usually really enjoying their sound palates and composition styles. It's not like I didn't like the OST, but nothing stood out to me at all, except for the aforementioned openings (I loved both of the openings, with the second OP tying for my favorite of the winter season alongside Dororo). So sound wise this is a relatively harmless show, with nothing that will really wow you, as well as nothing all that grating or unenjoyable. Besides the OPs. 7/10


Character is really the section that bothered  me the most, because to be blatantly honest, most characters don't really have that much. As much as I liked Shion and her design, we knew nothing about her besides the fact that she liked Rimuru and carried him around all over the place. The same can be said about basically all of Rimuru's groupies, and this is a huge problem as they are the characters we spend the most time with besides Rimuru himself. Besides that though, even if we were to learn more about these characters, they just get dropped like the stories get as Rimuru meets new people and travels to different places. Now, I 100 percent expect to see these characters again in the recently announced 2nd season, but that doesn't excuse how flimsy and 2 dimensional the characters are right now. Ranga is ok though. 3/10


With how much I ragged on this show so far, it's not liked I HATED it or anything, but it was definitely extremely disappointing to see everything I liked about this show in the beginning kind of just unfold on itself. That being said, the show was an inoffensive enough watch that I was able to kind of just binge the show and forget about it not feeling like i'd wasted my time. i'll give my enjoyment a 6/10


Overall this show is a 6/10 for me, but you have to understand how I rate anime. The only kind of show i'll rate a 5/10 or under is either something i absolutely hate (Akashic Records, SAO, Kino's Journey remake), or something that is just so obviously bad I have to give it a low rating, no matter how much I enjoyed myself while watching it (Ousama game, Hajimete no Gal), so giving Slime a 6/10 really isn't saying much for this show. I know I definitely wouldn't recommend it to anybody, and if I were to grade it I would give it a failing grade, but it's just so middle of the road and forgettable by the end of it's 25 episode run that I didn't really feel anything by the time the credits showed up, except for confusion, and a lot of disappointment.

I love this anime, more so than I can really properly type in a review. The TL:DR is that this series brings a smile to my face in the same way few anime have. It gives me genuine hope for humanity and what we can accomplish by working together as one. Rimuru earns every one of his followers not by sheer power alone, but by showing compassion towards those whom others wouldn't. He's powerful with magic sure, but he's nowhere near the strongest thing this world has to offer. 
Honestly this style of character and feel is very foreign in anime.  It makes megenuinely giddy seeing the different races getting along and past enemies making reparations and becoming friends. I still love dark and fast paced anime, but this take on Isekai is just so refreshing. \n\n
I'll end by saying I know this show isn't for everyone. Its a slower paced show and Rimuru doesn't seem to have a clear goal, at least at the start. But I want everyone to at least give it a shot if it entices you. I don't think you'll be disappointed.

"I'm not a bad slime!" The plot is very straight-forward and kept light-hearted. You could say it was dumbed down for the sake of pure entertainment. But there is something extremely beautiful about this simplicity. Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken has one appeal that you cannot find in other shounen anime. The drama here doesn't involve, dishonesty, betrayal, backstabbing, dirty tricks.. Yeah you heard me right. Problem1 appears, problem1 ends. Problem2 appears, problem2 ends. And it goes on and on that way without resolved case ever becoming an issue again. In a way that makes the characters unrealistically too good and the story, lacking somedepth. However that in itself makes the show very appealing. All of us are exhausted with work, school, everyday conflicts.. Why would we want to watch a stressful anime in our free time? There's not much relief from that. On the other hand, slime offers a beautiful world, a utopia, a peaceful universe that previously only exists in our imagination. A place where everyone understands and work together.. A TRUE BREAK from reality.


The fact that this has become a popular favourite is no surprise. It's rare to find an anime without overcomplicated drama that's dragged over the course of several episodes. Shitara Slime Datta Ken is a true dopamine rush with great subliminal message. "CAN'T HUMANS LIVE PEACEFULLY JUST LIKE THIS?". Overcoming our racial differences and darker past?


. U N I T E .

I had to write this as I felt there were other people on the internet who disagreed with my opinion that this is one of the greatest animes of all time. I would put it next to LoGH, 90's Berserk and Overlord for greatest anime adaptions of all time.
Story: 
They didn't write it, they are adopting it and I absolutely adore it. Its innocence and complexity both go hand in hand so well. They could have turned it into harem trash early on and wasted everything but they didn't. You know it's a story about a MC who is actually trying to be a protagonistand he does a really good job at being a decent human being (that was irony). It's not a grimdark presentation or anything, but they do tackle hard truths and go over tough topics in a way that makes you feel bad and then gives you warm fuzzies. The writing is that amazing. I should give this a higher grade than 10 for writing because my god is it amazing.


Art: 

Usually pretty good, but there are some sloppy, choppy battle scenes with less than perfect art. Everything else still looks really good.


Sound:

It sounds amazing in general, with the battle sounds having actual impact and the clanging sounding like the real deal instead of two two hollow poles being slammed against each other [insert new Berserk reference here]. What I really want to address is their selection of voice actors for the Japanese version and how perfectly they fit into their roles. The MC is a perfect example of a lower/middle management desk worker who is uncomfortable with his job. It's almost getting comical now that his voice hasn't changed despite his obvious confidence in himself as the ruler of a kingdom. The rest of the actors/actresses are appropriately cast as well and they did a great job in general.


Character:

It's why I'm watching the show. Go back to story, because it's a character story to understand why I love the MC so much. They nailed it on the head. The characters are understandable, grounded and realistic -- for a fantasy world involving dragons. The intrigue with them is never too deep, but the context around them is enough to give everyone at least a 2 or 3 dimensional character. Out of the dozens (literally) of characters introduced, no one has been the "I'm bad because I'm bad" character or the "I'm super righteous because I'm good" guy. We have back stories for every single minor character.


Enjoyment:

Read above. It's brilliant.

I have to say i'm really enjoying this so far. 
It captures my favourite tropes from other isekais, resulting in an almost perfect show.
While the show does have the classic OP protagonist, much like Overlord, most of the supporting cast are also OP in comparison with most of the inhabitants of the new world. Which in my opinion makes for a much more enjoyable show, as the MC isn't beating everyone alone.
This anime is great to look at, and the music and sound effects accompany the a battle scenes flawlessly.
I can't wait for the rest of the episodes to come out.

--Review may contain spoilers--
Mikami Satoru, your average businessman residing in Tokyo, Japan, gets stabbed and dies by a passing murderer. He gets reincarnated as a Slime in a parallel world. This Slime is not your average weak and lame Slime you'd find in every MMO game, but a Slime with special abilities and unique skills that make him overpowered. He meets Veldora, the Storm Dragon in a cave where he was reincarnated to, becomes friends with him and was named as "Rimuru Tempest".
Story (9): This is undoubtedly the isekai series to set the bar for the upcoming isekai series out there. It all starts offwith a decent way of someone going into a parallel world, but from then on, the anime blew my mind. At first, I was a little skeptical of the anime title because it would just be a story of someone reincarnating as a Slime, A SLIME out of all things, how could that be any interesting? But fortunately, I gave it a try and now I just can't wait for the next episode to air. Despite being overpowered as hell, Rimuru just wants to co-exist with humans and monsters alike, even creating his own village which consists of different monster races. With some comedy every now and then, you would expect this to be one of the best animes out there.


Art (9): Art is simply beautiful. Nothing much to say here.


Sound (9): The OP and ED are PERFECT. 


Character (9): Like I said, despite Rimuru being overpowered as hell, he doesn't use his power to destroy everything in his path. Usually someone with this much power would just dominate the whole world but this anime is different and I love it. Every character is special in their own way and they're not textbook like.


Overall Enjoyment (9): I definitely hope that this anime would go on as it is. Would definitely be a shame if it were to start of so good and become bad later on.

Okay, I'm usually rarely the type to go blindly into series, but this one just popped up in recommended for Goblin Slayer. The synopsis seemed fun, even without romance, which I sometimes like depending on the mood. There have been shows before, shows with very similar premise, and that is even more exciting with the fact on-board - I am the type to search for shows that are similar to the ones I liked very much before, or at least in the way of what I'd like to see in a series I imagine interesting for myself.
I started the first episodes and literally rushed itdown to 8 episodes. It has been ages since I saw such flowing story telling, visuals, fantasy THAT MADE SENSE and great communication among characters and the viewer. The visualization of the Rimiru's 'AI mind' is a lovely execution that appeals to me and lets you understand, receive, perceive the information even better, it does feel much more like-able as opposed if it was without such. It is the first show in a while that wasn't invoking a lot of obvious predictions in my mind - it only provoked theories that I wondered how and why would and could happen (especially seeing EDs/OPs), which would be cool to witness, but the action and the main character very well captures your attention not to bother with that! I love how the main character deals with the difficult decisions and how certain people, for example, the Conqueror of Flames, entrusts her life to the main character and her will is carried on. The main character, who appeared to have an uneventful life before, now has a life where he has an adventurous time, but still carries on the similar fate - to help, understand people. The fact that the main character has memories that can be applied to the current situations deepens the relation as well. The combat scenes and animation, in general, are very well done and presented, it is indeed slimeisfying watching a slime fight.


The only thing I hope is that this show does not fail on its way. The story will end eventually, everything will end eventually, but I wish the best of luck to the studio to execute it as well as those current episodes are airing. It definitely captivated me, and I do hope it continues to do so in the future!


Overall: 10/10, with the right to change if any of the criteria are affected by the series further progress


P.S. Keeping Rimiru in the form of Shizu definitely feels like something I look forward to seeing more often :>

Rebirth into a Different world, Okay.
Getting Overpowered skills and abilities from the start. Alright looking good.
Expecting a Cool looking Hero and Getting a Slime.. WTF?! WOW
When I first watched the anime , I thought of this as weird, unusual way to tell a isekai/ Another world story.Like its really a Slime, we are talking about here on the first view and perspective. 
It started a bit funnily and mysteriously , but after couple of episode, I grew fond and got hooked on the slime a.k.a Rimuru.
Okay Rimuru has Over powered skill right from the start, especially after meeting the Dragon, but he really doesnt actall proud and mighty, neither trying to look cool or trying to abuse his power or neither some weird intent. I am like wow i am really starting to like this and before i knew i got hooked. 

The story has begun on the basis and elements of a MMO RPG , and boy i am Loving it! 

When Rimuru came to the outside world from the cave, a whole lot of surprises awaited.


There are a lot of races of monsters, Humans and different kind of beings we get introduced to like in a mmo rpg, But what makes it interesting is, how he is underestimated greatly since he is C'MON A FREAKING SLIME! but our boy (Sorry Slime) rimuru keeps us surprised and proving his abilities and imagination can knock us out our seats but also he can make us laugh with his hysterics.


I love that kind of character development. He has good personality, loves to be serious and funny at the same time, his slimy expressions are so hysterical and enjoyable. He roams around acquires skills, he learns through a mysterious but amazing ability acquired through his afterlife choices., making allies and underlings, utilize his ability to the utmost. And you know the best part?? its just getting Started!


Animation is beautifully balanced with good colors, detailed drawings and good animation perfectly made for a isekai scenario by 8 Bit studios.


As for music, Takuma Terashima is performing the series' opening theme song "Nameless story and for outro Miho karasawa/ True sings the ending theme song "Another colony".


Many viewers are thinking that the main character will stay strongest forever. But gathering from the glimpses of other characters anime has shown us till now that's not the case at all. Soon the real story will begin and it will be get interesting and the story will keep on getting better i feel, 24 episodes is really worth to wait and watch how it unfolds. 


Definitely one of the Best Anime's to watch this Fall season. I hope more viewers can watch and admire this great piece of work. Definitely Highly recommended.

Other world anime is very good, I am a lover of other world anime. The story line in this anime is very interesting and I guarantee that the next episode will be even more interesting. The visual design offered in this anime slightly makes my eyes fascinated. Everything is good, starting from the sound of the characters that are in this instance, it can be said to be a little different from the others. I really enjoy this anime because the first of the characters presented is very interesting and certainly the second is the storyline. If you like other world anime whose characters arenot human but monsters, I highly recommend this for you

Don't listen to the negative reviewers. This show isn't what they expected, that's all. It's a very strange show, and it's going towards a very strange story. The first season is more of an introduction than a thriller. You'll like it, if you're into casual shows and strange stories!
If I'm forced to enter a longer review, I'll go on ahead saying that a lot of the story and topics seem to come out of the author's whim. But that's fine. Not every story has to be deep and dark. This is chill and mostly merry.
But there's an obvious twist in there. Time travel. Spirits. Reincarnations.Death and love.

A lot of people say it's just stupid because it has no plot, I personally disagree. It's definitely not for everyone but I really enjoyed it. Overall It is funny, interesting, and just overall enjoyable. I have to admit it lacks suspense but I really don't think that lowers it's quality at all. Also I really recommend the dub it's really good in my opinion I'm really excited for it's next season and hope it goes on for a while. I definitely recommend watching it, It's on the top of my Anime list. If you don't believe me watch it for yourself and enjoy it

I am a big fan of Isekai stuff, and, well, this anime is for me a tiny bit of enjoyment with a lot of frustration. I had read much the manga before watching the anime. (Oh, and btw I dropped watching anime around ep 15)
Where do the enjoyment comes from ? 
The story in itself is quite good as an isekai, especially the quite original stuff with slime. Drawings are really good, and most animations are as well. However, soundtracks are awesome, with a lot of variations, and generally used at the right time. 
Where do the frustration comes from ?
First, MC is too overpowered,and other characters are existent and selfless. Usually I love overpowered MC, especially overpowered progression ones. So, what is the problem here ? There is no feeling of tension, the MC never overcomes something, it just instantly solves every problems appearing. It may had be fun, as in OnePunchMan for example, but it isn't fun, or maybe not funny enough for me to laugh. \n
Second, the rhythm of the story is... Well, monotonic. Actually, there is no real rhythm. And I suppose this is what makes a big difference with the manga. When you read the manga, you choose the speed of the events, by reading slower or faster. Here you can't, so everything is way too slow, and you feel no difference between a casual meal and an "epic" fight. \n\n
Should you watch it ? \n
This anime is not so bad, it is just filled with a lot of useless and unpleasant moment. I would advise to either : \n
- Watch while doing something else (coding, cuddling with your cat ...) so you don't feel the monotony. \n
- Read the manga while listening to the OST of the anime\n\n
Please note : if it is your first "isekai" anime, you will probably just appreciate it, so watch it normally :)

Never in my life have I been so disappointed with an anime.
[MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD]
When I first started watching this anime, I thought it was great. The concept was awesome and the first episode had a pretty enthralling hook. I was sure that this would be an anime I would look back on with love and affection. The initial high of the first episode was great. But holy shit, it was a mad rush downhill from there.
I have a few things with this anime that I would like to discuss, namely: Rimuru's potions, characters, enemies, pacing, plot and general repetition.
First item on the list, Rimuru's potions.These potions are severely overused and essentially allow the main character's friends and comrades to rarely die or suffer any major consequences for fighting whatsoever. This gives every fight the feel that it doesn't really matter and removes any tension that you might feel during said fight. 


Second item on the list, the characters. Some of the characters in this anime were well thought-out and deep. An example of this is Satoru Mikami, a character who is flawed, but who also has his strengths. Sadly, this is the end of the list of good characters that come to mind, as the remainder of them are shallow and seem to only serve the purpose of filling out the ranks. The creators of this anime seem to have focused on quantity rather than quality, constantly introducing multiple characters at a single time and not bothering to give them any depth. Looking at them now, more than 65% of the characters could have been completely cut from the show without any adverse effects whatsoever. The lack of strong supporting characters is made even more unbearable by the protagonist being a Mary Sue and falling into the cliché of being nice because nice people are nice. 


The third item on my list is perhaps the biggest one for me personally. The enemies. Oh my god the enemies. The show devotes a decent amount of effort into alluding towards a huge threat that’s looming over the protagonist but fails to ever deliver, leaving an unfulfilling taste in the viewer’s mouth and a desire for something of any consequence to happen. The conflict that does occur seems to materialize itself out of thin air, as if the creators finally realised that nothing had happened for 6 episodes and had a panic attack, quickly drawing up an idea for some large thing to get set up for half an episode, then promptly get defeated before you can take a sip of your coffee. Lovely. It’s really disheartening for me to see an anime with such amazing potential and a great hook fizzle out into a big nothing-burger. 


The fourth item on my list is pacing, which tends to be closely tied in with the third and fourth items, but still deserves its own listing. This show has some serious issues with pacing. On the one hand, they spend an entire episode on one character’s death, and on the other, they only spend one episode on defeating a giant evil monster that’s been slumbering for 1000 years or whatever. These major issues combined with the first item on my list leave a supremely bitter taste in my mouth, as the characters involved don’t suffer any losses or damages when defeating ‘super evil villain with the power to destroy the planet #45’.


The fifth item on my list is the plot. While the concept of the anime is truly outstanding, the execution is what I would call piss-poor. One particularly jarring event of this occurring happens a little past the 2/3 mark of the series and features the main character completely fucking off from the place that the entire plot has revolved around and doing his own thing for someone that he knew for a single day and who died many episodes prior. I wouldn’t have minded this if it had been for a character I cared about, but, going back to characters for a second, the character that the protagonist was doing it for was one that hadn’t been well developed at all. And the plot largely revolves around this poorly-written and ill thought out character, constantly revisiting her 3 episodes of relevance.


This brings me to my sixth and final point, repetition. This was probably the most annoying part of this anime to me, as it is an egregious insult to the viewer’s intelligence. The way they repeat things over and over makes me think that the creators of the anime believe their viewers to have an attention span of less than a goldfish. Multiple pivotal plot mechanics are reiterated a multiplicity of times throughout the course of the anime and it really makes me feel a sense of contempt towards the creators.


In closing, I was extremely excited to watch this anime at first, as I had heard some good things about it. The sound and art were both good, but the plot and deeper concepts of the shows production were insanely lacking in both function and depth. I really wanted to like this anime, but the more I watched, the more I began to despise it.

That Time I Reincarnated as a Slime (Slime) was the show I was not expecting anything out of and then it surprised me by being pleasantly good only to slowly burn all that goodwill away leaving me with what I expected at the start another generic isekia (a genre where the protagonist is whisked away to another world) show.
Slime starts with how a lot of these shows do as an overworked salaryman is stabbed and murdered when he tries to defend a co-worker from a thief ( huh I guess Truck-kun must have been out sick for the day). He is then given the optionto reincarnate in another world and given some advantages that give him quite the edge against most of the denizens of his new world. After meeting with a mighty dragon named Valdora, they become friends and to free him from his imprisonment Rimaru ( the protagonist who is now a slime)absorbs him. This causes Valdora to disappear and creates a power vacuum in the forest where Rimaru has spawned. Rimaru comes upon some goblins and decides to help them.


From this point, the show turns into a lite kingdom building show. Which let me tell you if done right is one of my favorite genre's. But therein lies the problem. I much enjoyed much of the start where Rimeru starts a village, and it becomes more powerful and prosperous, but at the same time, it felt like the whole show was rushing to get through some story beats. This is problematic as a good kingdom building story needs a decent amount of time to explore the minutia of the process of starting a state. Slime is also the rare case where I have read the source material( keeping in mind I dropped it a ways back as I had caught up to the current issue of the light novel, but it never was enjoyable enough to go back and catch up) to know that they were skipping a lot of crucial details.  


As for the cast, Rimeru is a nice guy who tries to settle things amicably first in most scenarios. He was a reasonably exciting character to follow — the rest though not so much. No one was awful, but in that same vein, no one stuck out either. It has only been one day, and I have forgotten about most of them. I am sure I could tell you a detail or two but nothing that would make them memorable.


Animation wise Slime was nothing to write home about. In the sound department, it was the same nothing stuck out. The OP was good, but that was about all. 


All in all, Slime is going to be the show I forget about two weeks from now unremarkable in many ways. It is alright, but I would not recommend watching this show.

WHY I LIKED:
⬤ Unique sweet art style of 8 bit studios, nice 2D + 3D blend effects, rich nature themes
⬤ Sense of humour
⬤ Amazing worldbuilding
⬤ Graphic content (Some exposed wounds and dismemberment scenes)
⬤ The concept of being a shape shifting slime, OP main. I'm actually enjoying OPness of Rimuru as long as her character is developed and she keeps her cool.
⬤ No shounen cry in this show, thanks for leaving my ears well-tended.
⬤ Milim!
WHY I DISLIKED:
⬤ Rimuru is a straight loli who only turns into a slime when the animator grows tired... The 37 yo dude is just gone!
⬤ I kept hearing "Rimuru-sama! Rimuru-sama!" onceevery 2 seconds, is something wrong with me ? Shounen much ?\n
⬤ Worldbuilding was traded off with episodic and dull slice of life\n
⬤ The infamous fast pacing\n
⬤ Drop in animation quality\n
⬤ Hearing nothing but Rimuru's monotonous inner thoughts for many many episodes... I hope the VA is getting a decent share for that\n
⬤ Entire show was parade of new characters. Entire season 1 is actually a setup for Reincaranted as a Slime universe. But it doesnt change the fact that I had to go through it.\n\n
SUMMARY:\n
Rewatchability...\n
If it comes to that, first part gets a giant 9/10 from me. Second half barely makes a 6/10..\n
If you are anime watcher only, then dont be...\n
The reason I watched slime was the source material. I am trully in love with manga and LN, anime did ok job, but could have been better. My final score is a satisfying [[8/10]] ! Well done 8 bit studios!\n\n
In future, I truly want to give season 2 a 10/10 because the source material has a shot at it, looking forward to it.\n\n
Story: 8/10\n
Art: 8/10\n
Sound: 7/10\n
Character: 7/10\n
Enjoyment: 8/10\n\n
Overall 8/10\n

Before this anime was even released, it was seen as something that was to be made fun of, considering the bizarre idea and how everyone is so used to Isekai at this point. And when it did release, it was uh...good? There wasn't really anything that you could criticize about, it just seemed like a light-hearted and decent show. I mean it had strange charm to it, a great opening and characters with alot of potential.
But as the first few episodes went by, it seemed almost fun to the point where a lot of Anitubers were praising it for how good it was and yesit was good....for 12 episodes that is. After the Orc Lord arc passed, I started to realize the show's plot development is actual really slow, the story was going no where and barely any main villains / demon lords have been revealed or mentioned.


Yup, the opening was clickbait; can you believe it? A clickbait anime opening, holy shit. I cannot stress this enough, the opening not only showed a bunch of villains, it also showed the fantastic fights that we were going to get. But nope, what has our protagonist done in the past 25 episodes? Let's recap since the anime loves to do that by putting two of them in a finale.


Rimuru Tempest Has Achieved The Following Things In The First Season:

- Become a slime

- Enslave and befriend everyone he meets

- Eat a human

- Eat a pig

- Filler

- Let someone else beat a bad cgi monster with one attack

- Become a teacher

- Disappoint me


So in conclusion, Slime was an fun Isekai with alot of potential that turned into a boring mess that went no where and just ended off with 2 recaps. Now before I finish, just remember that behind that cute slime exterior, Rimuru is simply just your usual shitty Isekai protagonist in a usual shitty Isekai world. 


 The end.....oh shit there's another season FUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUU

There's a very specific kind of enjoyment which you can get from Reincarnated as a Slime, and the best comparison I can make - which might explain that enjoyment - is to time-loop movies. Movies like The Edge of Tomorrow or Source Code focus on an initially-incompetent protagonist being repeatedly put through the same sequence of events in the same place and trying to achieve some kind of goal. 
At the beginning, the protagonist repeatedly fails or dies because they don't know what's coming next. But eventually, they begin to map out the possibilities and anticipate the events in their reality, and figures out thebest way to get through the obstacles, or the right thing to do at the right time, in order to succeed. And at the point that the protagonist has finally managed to git gud, you get a vicarious sense of enjoyment from watching them.


That's pretty much what Slime is like, except, crucially, without the first part - which is to say, the part where the protagonist actually struggles. This basically turns the anime into a weirdly fun, oddly amusing journey through a fairly stereotypical isekai setting where the protagonist constantly makes the right choices, level-grinds (so to speak) in order to get all the powerful abilities he needs to consistently destroy his opponents, makes the right alliances to build up his kingdom, etc. If he was some kind of stereotypically handsome cool guy, this would probably be really annoying, but he's a literal slime, so it just becomes oddly funny to watch him take over a goblin village and turn it into a built-up town which is home to a multi-species coalition, or to befriend a legendary storm dragon just by being around and not being scared to talk to him. 


If this sounds undistinguished and like it might be kind of boring, that's because it probably would be, which is why I decided to be fair and give it 5 out of 10. Certainly, after the entertaining early parts where Rimuru the Slime consistently wrecks every opponent he faces and becomes the founder of a new nation, there's a deeply shitty final arc where he has to babysit a bunch of annoying kids, which sucks. However, if you have nothing else to do and find isekai kind of annoying, it might be fun to watch a show where a super-powerful slime basically rampages through an isekai setting just by being smart, having a bunch of rare abilities, and using his common sense.

TL;DR Review
I hated the first episode of this anime, it was cringy, annoying, and the way he died was lame (and his last line too, "wipe out everything from my HHD," what is this? 2003?). However, I grew to love this anime, and I wish there was more. My love for this anime grew exponentially, in fact. After powering through the first episode, I came to love all the characters (goblins, direwolf, etc) and Rimuru, of course. This is like One Punch Man, the main character is very OP, however, the anime contains it very nicely (not like SAO). I consider myself a pretty hardanime rater, so giving this an 8 is surprising. However, there always is some way to improve. Some of the jokes are lame and one specific character was definitely not in the anime long enough. You'll know which one if you watch this. So overall, I would say this is nice, just power through the first episode and I bet you'll grow to love this anime. \n\n
- Spacecraft555 UwU

OMG issa isekai y'all. who'da thunk one of those would come out. Oh, what's that? It's actually super charming and overall good with a huge budget for stellar animation? Well I guess it's worth checking out then. 
Dude gets killed, wakes up in another dimension as a lowly slime. PLOT TWIST he's super powerful. One thing I absolutely love about this show is that it justified it's main character being overpowered. Aside from the inherent resistances that come with being a slime. The MC eats an elemental dragon and then grinds for a month in the cave he spawned in. Then, after literally clearing thecave out, he leaves and goes on a wild adventure making new friends and unexpected allies. The story never gets too complicated, so sit back an relax. 


Like I said before, the art is great. The team clearly got plenty of money and time to make the show look good. Even the CG animation isn't too egregious and is sparsely used.  


Outside of the a good OP and ED, the music was mostly ambient. The sound effects ranged a little. Explosion and other magic sound good. Physical combat had some generic sword clanging noises, but the hand to hand stuff sounded good. 


The character designs are good. There are a ton of reoccurring characters and none of them look alike. The characteristics of these characters are pretty generic though. There are a few good comedy characters but most of the others fit into a stereotype. The good news is that, much like with a big j-pop or k-pop group, with so many characters you are bound to like at least one of them. 


My overall enjoyment was clearly enough to stay invested till the end. My enjoyment only tanked at the last bit when the MC goes to help some kids with their powers. It was kind of a boring way to end a 24 ep. run. However, with there being an ep. 24.5 out and the show being massively popular, I'm guessing we are getting another season. 


I would recommend the show. However, binging might be a bad idea as the show has a lot of story arcs, events and character introductions occur in rapid succession. It might be exhausting.

As I get older, I find myself often seeking out novelty when it comes to entertainment. Like with games, I still enjoy epic RPG and RTS games, but these days I'm mostly drawn to ones with unusual concepts like taking on the role of a shop keeper or a passport stamper rather than a world-saving hero.
Anime is no exception, so when I came across one about a slime - that most humble of monsters residing on the bottom rung of the RPG food chain - my immediate reaction was "sign me up, Scotty!"
Novelty concepts can only get you so far though; a lot hinges onthe execution. The execution of "That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime", or TenSura for short, is nothing special. The show is passable, and has moments when it delivers on the novelty premise. But overall it doesn't feel as fresh as I had hoped.


TenSura seems to have its fingers stuck in several popular pies. In case you haven't guessed from the synopsis-style name, the show originates from a series of light novels, set squarely in the trendy isekai game world, where girls are mostly big-breasted moebaits, all drawn to the protagonist like flies to a slimy poo. In addition, TenSura wants to be comedy, drama, action, fantasy adventure amongst other things. As a result of being spread so thinly, large parts of the series comes off as sterile, going through the typical motions of whatever it's trying to be with varying degrees of success, but never quite striking gold.


To start with, TenSura leans too heavily on its JRPG origins. While I can appreciate a few good jokes referencing the sort games the show parodies, the trappings of the settings are so in-your-face that it interferes with the storytelling. One of the main symptoms takes the form of the Great Sage. This is some AI-esq entity residing in the mind of Rimuru, our slimy main character, acting as his guide, his advisor and his analyst all rolled into one. I understand it's the in-story representation of a game's manual/system for easing in a new player, which is actually a pretty good parody idea. But that kind of gimmick can only be played for a quick laugh. TenSura chooses instead to have the Great Sage act as a uncomfortably big plot device, a cheap and deep well of knowledge which can be plumbed for exposition at the leisure of Rimuru, our slimy n00b.


This kick-down-the-barriers approach to storytelling is something TenSura does a lot. Not a single obstacle appear to exist in this fantasy world that Rimuru, our great slimy leader, cannot overcome within a couple of episodes, whether through brains or brawn. To be fair, I do like the fact that Rimuru doesn't just use his overpowered powers to muscle his way to solutions, he also applies the skills and experience of his previous life as a middle management salaryman. In this respect TenSura reminds me a little of Maoyuu. But it also suffers the same problem as Maoyuu, in that Rimuru operates at a level so far above everyone else that the story struggles to build up any tension or drama. With a few powerful attacks, Rimuru can decimate an army; with a few choice words or action, he can sway enemies into loyal allies. Everything feels too easy.


The dramatic elements of TenSura suffers particularly from the shortcuts taken by the writing. The anime's idea of fleshing out the characters consists of crowbarring in a tragic backstory right before they kick the bucket, and then expect you to care, even though you've only known the character for about half an hour. The underwhelming writing also shows itself in the dialogues, where we get treated to regurgitated "classic" lines such as "BAKA BAKA BAKA BAKA BAKA BAKA BAKA BAKA!!"


As an action series, TenSura does serve up some pretty cool battle sequences and flashy special effects. But Rimuru, our overpowered slimy protagonist, tends to drain the tension out of most battles he gets involved in.


Comedy is what TenSura does best, and the show delivers its fair share of amusing jokes. Unfortunately though, TenSura thinks it's funnier than it actually is. The show has a tendency to milk its jokes beyond their worth through over-reaction and repitition. When the jokes are funny, the milking diminishes the humour; when the jokes aren't funny, the anime just comes off as lame. Kind of like being in the presence of an irritating guy who insists on gaffawing at every joke he makes. It only gets worse when he starts telling the same ones over and over.


TenSura is at its most amusing when making good use of the novel premise. Had the show ended after one cour, it would have been better for it. But not content to focus on the one good thing it has, TenSura overextends in order to hit all the popular bases. Predictably, the novelty starts wearing off in the weaker second half, to which TenSura responds by turning to fake novelty, the kind which have become stone wall cliches by this point. For example, TenSura would introduce a demon lord who - get this - takes the form of a pink haired, hyper active moeblob with an annoyingly high pitched voice! Who could possibly have guessed! By this point, female characters in TenSura had become cancerous in general. It's like they were designed to irritate, and the voice actresses duly obliged by turning in a suite of nails-on-chalkboard-worthy performances. Also, The joke about Rimuru, our lecherous slimy harem-lead, nestling against a girl's jiggling jugs and being fawned and fought over by everyone not in possession of a dick may have been funny first time round, but it's certainly not good enough as a running gag.


Hmmm, this review came off harsher than I intended. I guess it's hard to expound on TenSura's strengths when it doesn't really have any outstanding points. Much like a slime, it mostly ambles along in an cutesy, inoffensive, mildly amusing kind of manner. "Jack of all trades" is another way of describing the show except labelling it as "jack" flatters it - it's more like an eight of all trades and certainly master of none.


Personal rating: +0.5 (decent)

This has to be my first experience actually bothering with a story featuring such an extreme case of Mary Sue protagonist (although, I'm aware it's kind of a golden standard for modern isekai stories) and I cannot say that it was a pleasant experience. 
The concept alone is solid: a not-particularly-successful guy (i.e. a virgin loser) dies and gets reincarnated as a slime (a mass of gelatinous fluid) in a medieval-like fantasy world. There's certainly a number of ways to handle such a story to a satisfying degree, but unfortunately, Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken takes the path of something that reminds me of areally poorly thought out RPG session. For anyone expecting to see our protagonist to struggle in his new body and work hard to overcome its limitations or maybe even question what it means to be human, I do not have good news. Rimuru, as our protagonist is eventually named, wakes up as a slime with a set of skills, supposedly stemming from his dying thoughts, that not only make him a really powerful slime, but even a contender for the title of the apex predator in the fantasy world that he gets transported to. As if things couldn't get any worse, Rimuru gets stronger with each defeated foe, thanks to a very convenient ability to "consume" things and add their properties to his repertoire. Needless to say, matches of strength in Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken are about as exciting as watching paint dry, as Rimuru easily overpowers all of his enemies and quickly befriends most of them (needless to say, strategizing is not required when might makes right and stronger opponents can be bribed with friendship). This is probably my biggest source of grief with this series. While some stories feature incredibly powerful protagonists who fight (both literally and figuratively) to find their own place in the society (a pretty common theme of supplementing external conflicts with internal ones), Rimuru does not fall into this trope, instead being presented as an extremely likeable individual, despite not actually showing much of a charm at any occasion - in a typical LN fashion, we have to take the author's word for it. Any sentient being he meets immediately falls head over heels for him. This gets so ridiculous, that even the few characters who are at first antagonistic towards him, despite not being shown as cut from a pure evil cloth (giving the audience hope for at least a hint of moral ambiguity), eventually succumb to his "charisma" and join his merry gang of monsters and humans seemingly driven by their unconditional love for Rimuru (this is the defining personality trait for the majority of the cast).\n
The series dangles another bait in front of the audience by presenting an idea of building a society of monsters led by Rimuru himself. This could potentially counterbalance the awful way characters are handled, by having the development of that society at the center of the story. However, yet again, the potential is completely squandered, as all the hurdles of building a functional community are either glossed over or entirely disregarded. At some point it really seems like the author wanted to delve a little deeper into the mechanics behind building a town or supporting a growing society, but for whatever reason, what we end up getting is so childish that even stories aimed at young kids seem to have more complexity. The city, future capital of Rimuru's nation, just grows without ever addressing the issue of resources needed for that to happen and the townsfolk (whose numbers quickly grow to tens of thousands) appear to feed exclusively on savage beasts hunted in the forest, never taking into consideration an abstract concept of agriculture. A significant jump from literal mud huts to brick-built houses, paved roads and exquisitely decorated interiors is justified by having a few craftsmen around. There's suspending one's disbelief and there's weaving a story in a way that even small children would find ridiculous. The last arc and "bonus" episodes make me wonder if the series was just poorly planned or was it a matter of production hiccups, but it's oddly fitting that a weak series was ended (at least in the first season) in such a lame fashion.\n
With lackluster, to say the least, characters and story, all hope to save Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken from being a complete waste of time lies in audiovisual qualities. Unfortunately, this is not a project of passion and technical aspects of the show fit the quality of content they have to present. Simply put, the animation is average. We get some really short and rare bursts of animation that could be considered artistic, but it's more exception to the rule. Sound is completely average as well, maybe even worse than that, with rather bland opening songs and some peculiar theme choices in key moments of the story (lighthearted tracks in seemingly serious scenes and vice versa).\n
All in all, my review paints a very bleak image of the series, but I really tried hard to not be too harsh (believe it or not), because at the end of the day, with all the laziness and stupidity Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken showered me with every week, I feel that the end result is more than the sum of its parts. At times it was mentally grueling, trying to wrap my head around the concept of someone creating a story with such a disregard for world building and character development, but ultimately, I were entertained enough to continue watching. It wasn't exactly a guilty pleasure, more of a morbid curiosity to see how bad it's going to get. I guess mediocre series like that are needed to appreciate the true gems more.\n
Would I recommend Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken to anyone? Absolutely not, unless they wanted to experience firsthand why isekai and light novel stories should be avoided. Is it the worst anime I've ever seen? Definitely not, but its awfulness compelled me to write this review, so there has to be something special about it.

Most isekai anime out there do the same things with there plot where someone is trapped in another world, they are strong as hell, and just learn to live with there new life or try and get out. But this anime does something different with those common trops and makes them either funny or entertaining to watch. I didnt start watching this show until half way through the season and when i picked it up i was so glad to watch a good anime that i started watching more anime again thanks to this show.
First the story. I really really love this story and whatthey do to move the plot foward. There were times were they might of skipped information or jumped months in advance, but just watching everything play out with the characters and what Rimuru Tempest does to make everyone equal and still help others out along his journey in this new world. Some parts of the story were a little boring, but when action happened and they feels you get at points are what makes this story really great in the world of isekai anime.


Next the art. The art in this anime was completely beautiful. Every scene had vibrant colors and outstanding visuals. The characters had great colors to them that made each of them stand out in one way shape or form and then the backgrounds also were touched on very nicely which made watching this anime even better. Even the background characters had some sort of color to them to make them not just another boring character and then some of the support characters with there style as well made every bit of art in the anime something to look to.


Next the sound. I will admit that some of the sounds in this anime were a little off, but all and all the sounds were really good. When there was a fight the sound sync was on point, when someone made a smirk or noise they were caught as well. The beginning and ending songs that played were also just as good when looking at sound. I think if the beginning of a anime can relay what the show is about and the music and also complement that then you should know your in for a good time and wanting to watch the new episode to see what else happens. 


Next the characters. All the characters that spoke in this anime had some sort of personality to them and each on had there time to shine in this anime. Each one had screen time and were not just one off characters where they were helped and never seen again. The were brought back a few times here and there which is better then nothing. Rimuru Tempest is a great character who didnt know nothing when coming to the world and was a fast learner to it which helped in a big way. Plus his personality is funny and great to watch when paried up with other characters like Rigurd,Ranga, and Shion all of which had there own personality as well and didnt make the plot slow with them in it.


Finally my enjoyment. I did enjoy watching this anime from the beginning to the end and im already glad that there will be a second season coming next year because i want to see where these characters go and what king of problems they will have to face along there journey to make new allies and face even more enemies along the way. Plus i really want to see how strong Rimuru can be with the predator ability he has.


Overall this was a really great anime to watch and i would recommend giving this a change if you like isekai anime or just want to watch something that can make you laugh and cheer at the same time.

That Time I Declined in Writing Quality
Welcome to TenSura, one of the latest additions to the niche and undersaturated genre known as "isekai" *laugh track plays*. Since there are about 17 isekais produced every anime season, studios have realized that in order to produce a truly successful isekai, they need to grab the viewer's attention in the first couple episodes. What happens after that? Eh, who cares. The show's already popular.
Story (4/10): I believe one of the greatest flaws of TenSura is the concept itself. The idea of a light-hearted Overlord may sound good on paper, but it fails in execution. Overlord works as ashow because Ainz is cool. The problem with TenSura is that Rimuru really... isn't cool. He's OP in a Kirito-like, boring way. After the pretty good first few episodes (up through the establishment of the goblin village) Rimuru just doesn't do anything interesting. I'm struggling to recall what actually happened in the arcs because there's not really anything connecting them. Rimuru just goes to some random place and gets more allies for his village. If you want to implement the one-dimensional Overlord plot of "man build empire", you can't have the main character be some nice guy that goes about building his empire by talking to random people. In essence, there's just nothing in the story department. There's no overarching plot, no cool/edgy factor, and no tension since Rimuru can literally defeat all enemies with his OP isekai protagonist skill. Oh yeah, apparently there was a comedy aspect here? I didn't find it funny, and apparently MAL didn't either since this show doesn't have a comedy tag.


Characters (5/10): Who? The only character listed as a "main" in TenSura is Rimuru, aka "OP blank slate boring man". The other characters include a harem of personality-less dolls, some side characters like Souei who attempt to inject some sort of edginess in the show, and random characters that appear once and are never brought up again. Shizu, the only character that may be argued to be "well-written" is nothing but a well-disguised MacGuffin. All she does is progress the plot, and nothing else. I'd like to talk about the random side characters in further detail. The problem here is that this season is pretty much an introduction into the universe. You get all of these characters that are simply introduced and left alone, like demon lord with clown servants, demon lord with blonde hair, knight girl who is hinted to be Shizu's disciple, those adventurers from the guild near the end of the show, and probably others that I've forgotten about. They're probably going to be important in the next season, but what about this season? 


Art (8/10): Pretty solid. The character designs are relatively memorable. The color scheme and the overall art help build the comforting, light-hearted atmosphere that the show strives for. The fights are nicely animated.


Sound (8/10): Idk why I'm giving this a high rating. There's this one OST that plays during every battle that's stuck in my head, so apparently that somehow makes the sound good. The OP and ED themes also nicely mirror the quality of the show. Just like the show was good at the start and turned into boring trash, the first OP and ED were good, and the second ones really weren't.


Enjoyment & Overall (6/10): TenSura was extremely bland, but I can't really give it a lower rating since it was decent enough for me to have the desire to watch every new episode. I'm really hoping that this was simply a setup season and that season two will be better, since this season seems to lay the groundwork and nothing else, but only time will tell.

Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken is an isekai that came out of nowhere and went back to the sources of the genre
After exploring the tragedy (Re: Zero) and the comedy (Konosuba), the genre returns to a version seemingly simpler and more refined, but that is all the more pleasant
[This review includes some spoilers, read at your own risk if you have not completed the series]
Story : 8/10
Classic. Simple but not boring, it takes a relatively common scenario among the isekai genre : a lambda man (who for once is not a NEET, a good point to clarify) dies and is reincarnated in another world, aworld threatened by the forces of evil.

However it is the fact that the protagonist is an overpowered slime that changes everything: here the character does not seek to gain power but in a first time discovers the world, then wants to build something

The story is quite different from a SAO (I will often mention SAO in this review, get used to it) but remains within the limits of the specifications of a traditional isekai


Art: 8/10

It does its job. It is not beautiful, certainly, but the fights are pleasant to watch and the animation in general is well done

The chara-design is relatively original. It keeps several clichés about fantastic creatures but manages to transform them and thus creates endearing characters

My only regret will be the use of the CGI several times, especially during the Charybdis arc. I'm still very sensitive to the CGI in anime and I admit to tolerate it badly, but during the aerial combat it is used to excess, especially on megalodons. I think it doesn't really stick with the whole atmosphere of the show


Sound : 7/10

The dubbing of the characters is well done and nice, I find that the voices stick to them rather well

Similarly, the various sound effects are well made (including the EXPLOSIOOONS) and we immerse a little more in the world of Tensei Slime thanks to them

However there is a very small flat that I may be the only one to have noticed: I did not find the OST very significant. It's just ... good. It does not bother me but I am very sensitive to music and I attach great importance to it, and at no point in the series did I say to myself at once: "wow, this piece of music is really great "


Characters: 9/10

One of the best point of the anime in my opinion

Already there's something that surprised me: the goodness of the characters. There are not many who are really bad or keep doing bad things. We have rather a big cast of fundamentally nice characters, then are added characters initially presented as villains / semi villains who then show redemption (but it's well done, not like the cheap villains in Fairy Tail), and finally we sprinkle all of a few "bad guys" who remain, there are a few and have not (yet) been really shown on screen

Rimuru is a very nice MC, because it is clear that he thinks a lot and makes logical decisions unlike many other MC (isn't it Kirito?). It is a pleasure to see a character making decisions that we would have made as well because they were logical and reasonable

The other characters are also very endearing because they are kind and loyal to Rimuru (I have always feared that there will be revolts, treachery or dissension but it never happened, so much the better!), My favorites being Ranga and Gobuta

I also like the fact that powerful people, be they sovereigns or demon kings, decide quite naturally to join Rimuru and to become friends with him, whereas in most other animes, their pride or their ego would have prevented them from doing it.

My only regret for the characters is that we didn't really see Veldra, who failed to break the seal during the first season. I really liked this character even though we saw him for a short time. Having a tsundere dragon becoming the best friend of a slime (or even a family member since they have the same name) and being extremely happy with it is adorable, and I'm really looking forward to see him in the second season


Enjoyment : 9/10

Surprisingly, this was not an anime that I looked forward to every week, but I had a good time watching each new episode (it's a little like my carrot for Monday, which pushes me to consider the day in a better way even if it's the worst of the week haha)

You can watch it without having to think a lot, it is full of good feelings without ever being cutesy, with also action and interesting intrigues. I also like the humor of the series, it's very present but it never falls into ridicule!


Overall : 8.20 / 10

The big isekai of the Autumn 2018 season will not have disappointed me and will have finally entertained me

I'm looking forward to watch the second season next year, hoping it will be as good as this one!




[French version]


Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken est un peu l'isekai sorti de nulle part et qui retourne aux sources du genre

Après avoir exploré la tragédie (Re:Zero) et la comédie (Konosuba), le genre revient à une version en apparence plus simple et plus épurée, mais qui n'en est que plus agréable


[Cette critique comprend quelques spoilers, lisez à vos risques et périls si vous n'avez pas terminé la série]


Histoire : 8/10

Classique. Simple mais pas ennuyeuse, elle reprend un scénario relativement courant chez les isekai : un homme lambda (qui pour une fois n'est pas un NEET, un bon point à préciser) meurt et est réincarné dans un autre monde, menacé par les forces du mal. 

Cependant c'est le fait que le protagoniste soit un slime assez overpowered qui change tout : ici le personnage ne cherche pas à gagner de la puissance mais dans un premier temps découvre le monde, puis veut y bâtir quelque chose

L'histoire est donc assez différente d'un SAO (je vais souvent mentionner SAO dans cette critique, autant vous y habituer) mais reste dans les limites du cahier des charges d'un isekai traditionnel


Art : 8/10

Elle fait son travail. Elle n'est pas magnifique, certes, mais les combats sont plaisants à regarder et l'animation en générale est bien faite

Le chara-design est relativement original. Il reprend plusieurs clichés concernant les créatures fantastiques mais arrive à bien se les approprier et créé ainsi des personnages attachants

Mon seul regret sera l'emploi du CGI à plusieurs reprises, et plus particulièrement lors de l'arc Charybdis. Je suis toujours très sensible au CGI dans les animes et j'avoue le tolérer assez mal, or lors du combat aérien il est utilisé à outrance, notamment sur les mégalodons. Je trouve que ça casse un peu l'ambiance


Son : 7/10

Le doublage des personnages est bien fait et agréable, je trouve que les voix leur collent plutôt bien

De même, les différents bruitages sont bien réalisés (notamment les EXPLOSIOOONS) et nous immergent un peu plus dans l'univers de Tensei Slime

Tout petit bémol que je suis peut être le seul à remarquer : je n'ai pas trouvé l'OST très marquante. Elle est juste...bien. Ca ne me dérange pas mais je suis très sensible à la musique et j'y attache beaucoup d'importance, et à aucun moment dans la série je me suis dit d'un seul coup : "wow, ce morceau de musique est vraiment génial"


Personnages : 9/10

L'un des points forts de la série selon moi

Déjà un côté qui m'a surpris : la bonté des personnages. Rares sont ceux qui sont vraiment mauvais ou qui multiplient les coups en douce. On a plutôt un gros casting de personnages foncièrement gentils, puis viennent s'ajouter des personnages d'abord présentés comme méchants/semi méchants puis qui font preuve de rédemption, et enfin on saupoudre le tout de quelques rares "méchants" qui le restent, mais il y en a peu et ne se sont pas (encore) vraiment montrés à l'écran

Rimuru est un MC très agréable, car on voit bien qu'il réfléchit beaucoup et prend des décisions logiques contrairement à beaucoup d'autres MC (n'est-ce pas Kirito ?). Cela fait honnêtement plaisir de voir un personnage prendre des décisions que nous spectateurs aurions également prises car elles étaient logiques et raisonnables

Les autres personnages sont eux aussi très attachants car gentils et loyaux envers Rimuru (j'ai toujours craint qu'il y ait des révoltes, traitrises ou dissensions mais ça n'est jamais arrivé, tant mieux !), mes préférés étant Ranga et Gobuta

J'aime aussi le fait que des personnes puissantes, que ce soient des souverains ou des rois démons, décident tout naturellement de s'allier à Rimuru et de s'en faire un ami, alors que dans la plupart des autres animes, leur orgueil et leur égo les en auraient empêchés.

Mon seul regret au niveau des personnages reste qu'on a pas pu vraiment revoir Veldra, qui n'a pas réussi à briser le sceau pendant la première saison. J'ai beaucoup aimé ce personnage même si on l'a vu peu de temps. Le fait d'avoir un dragon tsundere devenir le meilleur ami d'un slime (voire un membre de la famille vu qu'ils ont le même nom) et qu'il en soit extrêmement content est adorable, et je suis vraiment impatient de le revoir dans la deuxième saison


Appréciation : 9/10

Etonnamment, ce n'est pas un anime que j'attends avec impatience chaque semaine, mais je passe un agréable moment à regarder chaque nouvel épisode (c'est un peu ma carotte du lundi, qui me pousse à bien considérer la journée même si c'est la pire de la semaine haha)

On le regarde sans se prendre la tête, c'est rempli de bons sentiments sans jamais être mièvre, avec également de l'action et des intrigues intéressantes. J'aime aussi beaucoup l'humour de la série, très présent mais qui ne tombe jamais dans le ridicule !


Total : 8.20/10
