Le gros isekai de la saison Automne 2018 ne m'aura pas décu et m'aura au final bien diverti

J'ai plutôt hâte de regarder la seconde saison l'année prochaine, en espérant qu'elle soit aussi bonne que celle-ci !

That time I got reincarnated as a slime is an interesting show, if you asked me what my favourite show was in the fall season I would have said slime without a doubt, that’s not the case after the winter season. It’s not that it got worse or anything, it’s just that it never changed in any way, all of the interactions are almost the exact same every time. There are 2 different ways that an interaction with a new character can happen 
1. Arrogant new characters appear and underestimate our power protagonist(s), when shown the power of the protagonist they become humbled and areshocked by how forgiving he is of them for their previous arrogance 


2. The arrogant character is a very powerful loli that switches sides when given food


In both cases it’s likely that they join Rimuru and if there are non human characters involved they get names and become very human looking, it gets old after a while, it’s the same thing every time with very little differences, not to mention that’s there’s no suspense because the protagonists can seemingly fight anybody and anything without any problems. 


It’s not that I hate the show or anything, it has very good animation and I love watching his little nation grow, but in the end it’s strengths aren’t enough to put it at an above average rating, if you like isekai then you’ll probably like this but for me this is a 5/10

Please note this review is intended to be read by those that have finished watching Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken and while care has been taken to minimize story related spoilers there may still be spoilers within character analysis. You have been warned. 
Based off a popular manga and light novel of the same name Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken which is better known by its English title of That time I got reincarnated as a slime and its synonym’s of Tensura is a fantasy and shounen anime that gives us the opportunity to see what will happen if a mid-aged office worker who seemsto be content with his life as just another salaryman that lives in the metropolis of Tokyo were to one day while providing his juniors with some well earned life lessons were to suffer a truly untimely death that would rather than transport him to the netherworld where all deceased would go would rather see him transported to an alternate world that’s more akin to that of a game world than the real world. However, rather than being transported to said world as a human being as one would expect he would instead be reincarnated as something that can be said to be the lowest of monsters which is that of a slime. 


The Isekai genre of anime, light novels and manga fame is a well-trodden one thanks largely due to the ease of use of its main concept which is the transportation of a being human or otherwise from one world to another parallel world. Looking back through the previous anime season’s one can see many great examples of the genre such as the famed Konosuba, Re Zero and Log Horizon series. However, apart from the genre, there is one other common theme that links these series together and this is the fact that whichever world the main characters of these series find themselves transported too they will still remain as human. In this Tensura can be said to be somewhat unique as after death the main character of the series rather than being reincarnated as a human as previous series have done instead is reincarnated as a slime a creature that is seen to be the lowest of monsters. 


This concept of being reincarnated as a creature rather than a human being I thought was interesting and notable as while providing a much needed breath of fresh air into the genre it also provided an interesting opportunity to see a new fantasy world from the perspective of a human being that while being in the form of a monster has the knowledge that comes from the fact that he retains the memories that he had in his previous life. This combination of being a monster that has memories of subjects and matters that are visually unknown to the people of this new world was what can be said to be the main reason that drew me to the series as this knowledge of the mc allows him to not just create magic, organizations, towns and societies that are visually unknown to the world but also allow him to change and advance the various races that inhabit the land and dispel the sense of inherent distrust that exists between the various races by forging alliances between them and teaching them to respect and treat others fairly. This concept of trying to instill peace and order within the new world while making sure that each race is able to advance in tech level in uniform fashion, I felt was admirable as Rimuru’s actions not only changed himself and his allies but also the world around him as well. This sense of trying to change the world through diplomacy and teaching of new concepts to others in order to change the various races and their views on others ensured that this series was one of the best series of this season and I was glad that I decided to watch the series from start to finish. 


The overall story for Tensura takes place in a fantasy world that while having the standard races of humans, elves, dwarves, orcs, and goblins also have some unique exotic races like the ogre’s, direwolves, dragons, demons and Dryad’s that manage to fit surprisingly well into the fabric of the world’s races. Similar to fantasy realms of other series the various races of the world are broadly divided into regions in which they inhabit with towns and villagers being the most common forms of settlements. In this world, while peace was indeed in full reign it can be said that not every race got on with each other with harmony and indeed conflict would break out with the suddenness of a flare. The series overall story follows the life of Rimuru tempest a human being from the modern world who after suffering an untimely death in his home world was reincarnated as a slime in this new fantasy world. Rather than become an OP fighter slime as one would no doubt expected him to be Rimuru instead decides to take it slow and learn not just about this world but also get a feel for not just his newfound abilities but also of how the various races that inhabit the land view him and other races that they share this land with. This sense of taking things slow and learning not just about how each race lived in the world but also how their societies can be advanced and integrated with others so as to create a sense of unity within the world and help bring about peace can be said to be one of the main themes of the story and a theme that I felt took great advantage of not just the various types of races that existed within the world but also of the sense of democracy that came from Rimuru’s origin of being from a modern civilized democratic society like modern day Japan. 


Rimuru Tempest 


Rimuru Tempest portrayed by new seiyuu Miho Okasaki is one of the main characters of the series and is the main protagonist of the series. In his initial form, Rimuru was a mid age salaryman that lived-in modern-day Tokyo that while having everything that life could have offered him aspired what many people in his position would wish for which was to have some sort of excitement in his life that would spice things up for him. As a result of this despite the demands of his job and the stress that came from modern-day city life, he still maintained a cheerful and friendly personality that enabled him to get on well with others easily a trait that unfortunately proved to be his undoing and caused him to become an unfortunate casualty. After his reincarnation as a slime Rimuru’s personality changed dramatically. While still retaining his friendly and cheerful nature Rimuru also developed a sense of curiousness to explore this new world that he had been transported to and a desire to test out the various things that he had discovered. While being reincarnated as a slime would no doubt have taken an average human being some time to get accustomed to it can be seen that even as a slime, he had not lost any of the traits that he had in his previous life. While curious to explore Rimuru was also intelligent and fast thinking and wasn’t afraid of experimenting with his new-found powers and form now that the old-world rules did not apply to him. This can be seen well in his attempts to create new attacks and trying them without any kind of safeguard in place. This sense of wanting to test out ideas however wasn’t restricted to the testing of his powers however as Rimuru true to his nature was also willing to experiment with somewhat riskier ideas like creating completely new societies that have more than one race in them a plan that could easily have backfired had it not been Rimuru that was doing it. This shows that while developing a sense of curiosity Rimuru had also developed a sense of creativity as well and one that wasn’t restricted to one world’s knowledge and was willing to create a wide manner of things no matter how outlandish they may sound to the people of this new world with the town of unified races that Rimuru created over the course of the series to be a good example of this. 


Despite being transformed into a slime it can be seen that Rimuru has lost none of the friendly and easy-going nature that defined his original self. This can be seen well in the many first encounters that he has with the many races that inhabit this world. Despite commanding a number of impressive abilities that would have given most people pause it can be said that Rimuru is a calm and understanding person by nature that tries to ensure that all parties are relaxed before interaction begins. While this can be seen to be a weakness of sorts here it can also be said to be the opposite as Rimuru as a result of being freed from the stress and demands of modern day life now has all the time that he needs to analyze the various situations that he comes across in his journeys and come up with the best possible answers that can benefit all parties. While noted to be someone that preferred to deal with situations via diplomatic means it can be said that Rimuru was by no means someone that was afraid to counter those that were rude to him or his allies and was willing to verbally spar with those that he felt had offended him or his friends something that I felt matched well with his friendly and caring nature while also showing off his intelligence and his wittiness. A good example of this is shown in the initial exchanges between Rimuru’s town and the lizardmen. In the beginning of the series largely due to the inexperience that he had in dealing with new races, Rimuru was noted to have a certain lack of awareness on the feelings of others and the needs and desires of the races that he encounters over the course of the series. As a result, in the beginning while his orders were certainly followed accordingly it can be seen that not all races were ready to follow him. However as the series goes on and Rimuru got to see and understand the kinds of struggles, needs and desires that each race had within them Rimuru gradually began to realize that in this world each race was like an individual person that had their own unique beliefs, needs and desires and as a result gradually learned to be more considerate towards the feelings of those around him something that I felt fitted well with Rimuru’s role as a leader. 


Overall the character of Rimuru I felt was an interesting one and while death might have been a traumatic experience to some it can be said that the death of his initial body and the act of being reincarnated as a slime in a brand new world had the opposite effect as it instead gave him the freedom to for the first time in his life take things easy and slow and actually enjoy the new world in which he had been sent into. Seeing Rimuru manifest the infinite sense of curiosity and creativity that had been suppressed by the demands of modern day life and use it to try and change not just the races that he encounters in his travels but also the world as a whole as well in an effort to create a peaceful society I thought was an interesting development and direction for his character as while for the most part it derived from his desire to live an easy life in this new world it also derived from both the fact that he was from a modern democratic society where peace was second nature. This sense of combining character development and direction with the personal beliefs and desires that one has learned from hard-earned life experience I thought was interesting as it added a more personal feel to the development of Rimuru while also matching well with the series overall theme of advancing society. 


Shizue 


Shizue Izawa portrayed by Yumiri Hanamori of Yuru Camp fame is one of the main supporting characters within the series and is one of Rimuru’s allies within the series. In her initial appearances Shizue who is more commonly known as the masked swordswoman on account of both her skills as a swordswoman and the mask that she wore when on duty was seen to be a quiet, calm and composed young woman who despite her fame was kind, caring and polite to all that she met in her journey. While a quiet and composed person by nature Shizue was also someone that was shown to be curious about matters and subjects that she had not seen before which is best shown in her reaction at seeing races that would otherwise have been hostile to her instead show her kindness and care. At the same time despite her fame as a famed swordswoman Shizue was someone that was noted to prefer observing and understanding new situations before making a decision rather than simply drawing her sword and fall back on standard protocols of eliminating races on the off chance that they are hostile something that I felt put her in good stead and ensured that she managed to bond well with not just the members of Rimuru’s future town but also Rimuru himself. 


While a kind and caring person by nature and one that would not hesitate to use her powers to protect her friends and comrades from harm from the onset it can be seen that Shizue was someone that preferred to keep her true emotions and feelings hidden behind her mask. As the series goes on it can be seen that Shizue’s mask rather than merely keeping her identity a secret from those that she doesn’t trust also serves as a sort of sanctuary of sorts for her as it is only within the mask that Shizue is able to reveal her true feelings. Unlike the kind and confident personality that she shows on the surface it can be seen that beneath her mask Shizue is someone that’s emotionally fragile and lonely that stems from not just her role and position as a famous swordswoman but also from the many regrets that had formed within her as a result of the many discoveries that she has made regarding not just her own powers but also that of her charges as well. As a result of this it can be seen that in addition to being emotionally fragile and lonely Shizue also possesses a deep fear that perhaps one day if she’s not focused that her powers would not only go berserk but also injure those that she was supposed to be protecting. As a result of these fears, it’s perhaps unsurprising that Shizue would desire to find and befriend people that she can share her secret pain and grief with but alas for her she was not successful until she encountered Rimuru. Though the interactions that Shizue had with Rimuru were relatively short ones it can be seen that in her last days Shizue thoroughly enjoyed spending her time with Rimuru as for the first time in her long life she was able to reveal to someone that she trusted all of the pain and regrets that she had been holding beneath her mask for so long and the one wish that she despite her power was unable to fulfill that she hoped that Rimuru her first confidant would be able to in her place. 


The character of Shizue I felt was an interesting one as the contrast between her position and role as a powerful swordswoman that was widely seen by many as a powerful but kind, steadfast and dependable fighter that can face down the fiercest of enemies with icy calmness and her hidden side of a lonely, insecure and emotionally fragile young woman that longed to find someone that she could pour her heart out to being especially so. In a way despite the way that society views her it can be seen that Shizue was somewhat of a tragic figure as she was not only brought to this world against her will but also forced to take up the role that she was ill-suited for. While persevering in her duties as a valued member of society in an effort to both protect the innocent but also find a way back home Shizue much to her horror found that not only will her control of her powers start to decrease as she ages but that her valued charges would also start to enter the final roads of their lives as well. This combination of a professional struggle and the hidden personal struggle that she tries hard to conceal with from friends in an effort to not worry them I thought was well done and conceived as it added a more emotional element to her character’s struggles and made her relationship with Rimuru that much more special. 


Shion 


Shion portrayed by veteran seiyuu Mao Ichimichi of Aoki Hagane No Arpeggio and Digimon adventure Tri fame is one of the main supporting characters of the series and is one of Rimuru’s main allies within the series. A member of the Ogre race and one of the survivors of that village Shion in her initial appearances was seen to be a proud, confident, stubborn and a somewhat fiery person by nature that preferred to strike first rather than use diplomacy when meeting new races.  This last trait is shown well in the first encounter that she and her party had with Rimuru and his village. However, despite her tendency to act first Shion is also someone that can be said to have a strong sense of honor and willing to respect those that are able to show their resolve even when they are backed into a corner which I felt goes well with her spirit as a warrior. In line with this Shion is someone that isn’t afraid of facing down strong foes on the field even if the said foe has proven to be much more powerful that she is. 


After becoming a member of the village and after being uplifted by Rimuru Shion’s personality gradually starts to change. While still retaining her strong loyalty to her fellow ogre’s and to the village that acted as their homeland Shion like the rest of the ogre’s also developed a strong loyalty to both Rimuru and the town that he had created due to the fact that he not only gave them a new location in which they can call home but also allow them to get revenge on the orc lord that was responsible for the destruction of their village. However, unlike the rest of the ogre’s it can be said that with Shion’s loyalty comes an intense romantic interest in Rimuru which while excessive at times often provides a good deal of comic relief for her character with notable examples being how bad she is at cooking. As a result of this dual amount of affection and loyalty that Shion has for her lord and the village it can be seen quite clearly that she’s very proud of Rimuru and of the notable alliance that he had formed with the various races that inhabit it and as such she will not tolerate any type of slander of either. 


Shuna 


Shuna portrayed by veteran seiyuu Sayaka Senbongi of Girlish Number and Clockwork Planet fame is one of the main supporting characters of the series and is one Rimuru’s main allies within the series. A member of the ogre race and one of the survivors of that village Shuna is also Benimaru’s younger sister and a true princess of that race. From her initial appearance Shuna was seen to be a quiet, perceptive and intelligent person by nature that unlike her brother Benimaru and her friend Shion was seen to understand the value of diplomacy and the need to be cautious and rational when dealing with new races and situations. While a quiet person by nature Shuna was also noted to possess a degree of bravery that one would hardly expect from a quiet girl like her and she was willing to go to great lengths to ascertain and confirm a theory that she had discovered. This is shown well during the first encounter between Rimuru and the members of the Ogre’s of which she was a part off when she stepped in to defuse the quickly escalating situation that transpired between the two parties. 


After joining the village and being uplifted Shuna like the rest of the ogre’s gradually began to change in personality. While still retaining her trademarked quiet and calm nature Shuna also began to develop a desire to be useful to her new lord and to be useful enough to be relied upon by giving her a degree of responsibility something that I felt was not just cute but also showed her desire to be of better use to her village and to her new allies. While certainly weaker than her fellow ogre’s in frontline combat Shuna however more than made up for it with the vast knowledge that she had in medicine and in this, it can be seen is where she truly shines. While clearly intelligent Shuna true to her personality did not show any degree of arrogance in her actions and indeed she was willing to not just learn about different cultures but also techniques that have been created by other races which does well in showing her hardworking and earnest nature. Like Shion Shuna too is shown to have a great deal of affection for Rimuru but unlike Shion who is more open with her feelings Shuna’s feelings towards her lords tend to be more subtle. Though not often seen the rivalry between the two friends over their affections for Rimuru are always amusing to watch and add a sense of hilarity to the scenes in which they take place. 


Millim 


Millim portrayed by veteran seiyuu Rina Hidaka of Sword Art Online and Ryuuou no Oshigoto fame is one of the main supporting characters within the series and is one of Rimuru’s main allies within the series. A young human female and also one of the oldest of the demon lords that currently inhabit the world to which Rimuru calls home Millim from her initial appearance is seen to be a positive, curious and earnest young lady that approached each new situation with both determination and a somewhat childish desire to be surprised. Unlike the more traditional image that can be inferred from that of a demon lord Millim rather than being a brooding, dark and cynical person who enjoys making mortals dance to their tune is quite the opposite in that she while disliking the various rules and agreements that are in place within the world is instead someone that can be said to be somewhat of a free spirit that approaches each day with cheerfulness and a desire to try out new food and experiences and meet new surprises aspects that are more in line with that a average teenage girl than that of a demon lord. However, this schoolgirl side of her will vanish once Milim gets serious for this is when she shows off the demon lord side of her that’s she known for far across the land. 


In contrast to Millim’s default schoolgirl self which is kind, caring and protective of her friends and allies Millim’s demon lord self can be said to be the total opposite. In this form to which she will adapt when things get serious Millim’s kind and caring personality is instead replaced by that of arrogance and confidence in her abilities as a demon lord and unlike in her alternate self she will not hesitate to strike the enemy before they can prepare for her. While hitting hard and fast with her attacks it can also be seen that Millim also takes great care to observe her enemy and use the knowledge that she gained in centuries of learning magic and actual combat to deal with the enemy’s attacks while making sure that her own are as effective as possible showing that while she may look relatively young for her role that Millim’s combat skills are indeed genuine. This is shown well within the first fight between Rimuru and Millim in which she was consistently able to get the upper hand in that fight despite Rimuru’s attempt to counter her. Though Millim’s demon lord form is indeed powerful its interesting to note that even in this form Millim’s curiosity to experience new things are still present to some degree and can easily be exploited to end things peacefully as shown in the manner of how Rimuru ended the fight that he had with her. In this, it can be seen that while Millim herself is a fearsome combatant that can match Rimuru quite easily in terms of combat strength that she’s a child at heart that can easily be distracted when presented with things that she hasn’t seen before. 


The character of Millim I felt was an interesting one with the contrast between her two forms and with them their respective personalities being especially so. While the image that most people would have upon the mention of the term demon lord would no doubt be some scheming  demon that sits on a throne somewhere working on his next big plan of conquest Millim is a bit of an exception to this rule as if one did not know her personally one would no doubt think that she was just your average teenage girl that was enjoying the youth that all girls would go through before adulthood. Indeed, it is this view that truly makes her stand out for unlike other demon lords that are shown in the series Milim while a genuine demon lord with combat abilities that are equal to or above that of Rimuru rather than treat others with arrogance and cruelty instead treats all that she encounters with respect, politeness and cheerfulness that add a degree of freshness to her character. More than anything seeing Millim gradually learn about society and seeing how she befriends and bonds with the members of the village while enjoying all of the benefits that comes from living with those that she gradually learns to care about was an interesting experience for both us the viewer and for Millim herself as well. This development is seen especially well when Millim sees her friends and allies getting hurt by outsiders as it is here where we can truly see Millim’s strong desire to protect them by unleashing her demon form. Seeing Millim not just learn about what a society is like but also see the value of friendship and bonds that can be found there I felt was interesting and highlighted just how much Millim has grown as a character. Seeing her switch between forms so readily in order to protect those that she considers dear to her was also endearing as well. 


AMV 

In terms of animation, I thought that the various locations and settings that were featured within the series were both well thought out and designed and featured quite a strong variety of terrain that matched well with the races that called those locations their homes. Notable examples of this included the goblin village, the dwarven homeland of Dwargon and the Freedom academy that housed the students that Shizue was trying to save. Of these locations the Goblin village which later transforms into a city that serves as the capital of Rimuru’s Jura Tempest Federation is undoubtedly  my favorite due to the fact that the city was essentially built from the ground up using both the ideas that Rimuru had from his former home and also because of how it symbolized the core beliefs of his dream which was to build a city that housed citizens of all races that can live alongside each other without fear of tension and disagreements that could escalate into conflict. 


In terms of character design, I felt that the series featured quite the large variety of both races and creatures within its overall story. Each of the races within the series whether it was the beasts that Rimuru and co had to fight within the series or the individuals of each race I thought was very well designed and detailed. While the standard conventions of how humans, elves and dwarves looked were established long ago I thought that the series did well in showing the more exotic races that weren’t featured in conventional work with the series depiction of the ogre’s, Dryads and goblins being especially well done. The series depiction of Orcs as pigs I felt was an interesting take on how the race looked. In terms of combat animation, I thought that the series featured some pretty impressive fights that while usually short were well thought out and made great use of both terrain features and simple but creative use of tactics and Rimuru’s own abilities. Notable fights within the series that I enjoyed seeing was the battle between the goblins and the direwolves, the battle to defend the village from Ifrit, the battle against the Orc Lord and the battle against demon lord Millim. While Rimuru is the main character within the series I was also thankful in that the various races that he had uplifted with the naming were also given the chance to show off their improved stats within the series as well with the Kijin in particular being able to make a satisfying bang in their combat debut.  


In terms of music, the series made use of two opening themes which was Nameless Story and Meguru Mono that was sung by Takuma Terashima and Three ending themes which were Nameless story that was sung by Takuma Terashima, Another colony that was sung by TRUE and Little soldier that was sung by veteran seiyuu singer Azusa Tadokoro. All of these songs I felt were catchy ones with Meguru Mono, Another Colony and Little Soldier being my favorites. Of the series OST, I felt that it did a great job of dividing its time between peaceful and calming music for scenes that showed the development of characters and infrastructure and more dramatic music for the combat scenes. At the same time, I also felt that the Opening and ending themes of the series was used well to both give us a look at characters that have yet to appear within the series and at the same time show the development of said characters and the town as the series progresses. While certainly subtle I felt that this aspect was used well to show not just how many friends and allies Rimuru has made over the course of the series but also in how much he changed the world as well. 


In terms of voice acting I felt that the series main voice cast all did an excellent job at portraying their assigned characters whether they were main ones or support ones. In particular I feel that Miho Okasaki, Yumiri Hanamori, Mao Ichimichi, Sayaka Senbongi and Rina Hidaka deserve special praise as I felt that they all did an excellent job in portraying the characters of Rimuru, Shizue, Shion, Shuna and Millim respectively. Miho Okasaki in particular really impressed me with her portrayal of Rimuru and I hope that the experience that she had gained in portraying Rimuru would help greatly in allowing her to develop her skills as a seiyuu and make a career within the seiyuu industry. In addition, while I didn’t cover them within this review, I also thought that Makoto Furukawa, Asuna Tomari, Chikahiro Kobayashi and Rie Tanaka all did an excellent job at portraying the characters of Benimaru, Gobuta, Ranga and Treyni respectively. 


Overall conclusion 


Overall Tensura was an anime that I really enjoyed watching and I have to say it’s definitely one of this season’s best animes. Its main strong points in my opinion is its excellent and unique premise, strong story, well designed and developed characters, excellent voice acting, its strong emphasis on real-world issues like nation building and integrating different races into one society and its emphasis on changing the world through society and tech advancement rather than through military means. At the same time, I also thought that the series did a great job at skillfully blending the genres of comedy, action and fantasy together something that can be said to be inherently tricky within an anime. 


The overall premise of Tensura which is the death and reincarnation of a human being from the modern world to a parallel is nothing really new since it serves as the main form of transportation for the Isekai genre. However, while the form that they would reincarnate into can vary substantially being reincarnated as a slime which is a monster that is widely considered to be the lowest on monsters has to be the most unique form I ever seen. While being reincarnated as a slime instead of a normal human being that can make much more effective usage of his modern-day education and memories can be seen as a disadvantage as after all very few people take slimes seriously the form of a slime can also provide some unique advantages that the larger forms lack such as a unique perspective on how monsters behave and operate in the world, deception and misdirection and a less threatening appearance the last point being especially useful for Rimuru given his focus on diplomatic means to resolve crisis. All in all I felt that the form of a slime that Rimuru took after being reincarnated rather than give him a host of disadvantages that many would have expected actually provided a great deal of unique advantages that allowed him to not just overcome the many different trials that comes from his adventures but at the same time act as a safety net due to a slime’s unique body structure. More than anything I felt that being a slime rather than say a human being actually had a hand in contributing to Rimuru’s success in convincing the various races to work together with him. 


The overall story for the series I felt was one of the series main strong points and was one that I really enjoyed. Typical Isekai stories tend to focus on a hero that after being reincarnated in the new world would one day receive a quest in which they must fulfill a difficult quest that would see them face anything from dragons to demons while protecting humans from the predations of the evil demi humans and monsters that inhabit the dark places. However, what if this story is replaced by one where the main focus rather than focusing on dealing out death to anything that’s not human instead is replaced by one where the main focus is on learning about the various races that inhabit the land, uniting them and advancing their tech level in order to instill changes to not just their living conditions but also create an ability to evolve their society so that they can be equal to their surrounding countries and no longer be seen as a mere monsters. It is this focus on learning, expanding and advancing of the various races that Rimuru encounters over the course of his journey that can be said to be the true joy of this anime as we get to see Rimuru not just overturn the concept that all monsters were threats to humans by not just giving them personality but also their unique culture, taste’s, likes and dislikes aspects that many would argue that only humans would have. Seeing Rimuru recognize this by treating them not as beasts but as humans by giving them names and working with them to forge bonds with others and make friends and not enemies that culminated  in the creation of not just the town of Tempest but also of the larger Jura Tempest Federation I felt was immensely satisfying as more than anything it represented a great change within the series not just to the various non-human races but also to the many human nations as well. 


Overall Tensura was an anime series that I really enjoyed, and it is undoubtedly one of the seasons best animes on account of its unique premise, strong story, excellent voice cast, its skillful use of real-world issues that aren’t usually seen within anime and its emphasis on diplomacy rather than on physical might. As a final score, I would say that Tensura easily deserves a score of 9/10. While the series started strong I felt that the story arcs near the end while introducing some interesting new characters didn’t expand them enough to make them compelling.

While I do enjoy a different take on the isekai genre i do feel like this anime is not all that different to any other anime.
Honestly the characters are bland. Main character is so Mary Sue and overpowered it just seriously gets to predictable as the series progresses. Barely anything is a problem for our main character it's so bland.
The supporting cast are into, what I can see, into 2 categories: Dumbass and boobs
Seriously nearly any female character is depicted with either giant boobs or "flat chest"
Their only contributing is to fall for the main character without any rhyme or reason. 
I feel that theonly support characters with any development are the Male characters. And they are ok, but not enough for me to care to much about them. \n\n
And while the fan service isn't all that much here it is pretty obvious when it gets on screen. \n\n
If you like more developed characters, even the support cast, then I would recommend you rather watch Log Horizon. A good isekai story with enjoyable characters that is actually believable

Story: 
Nothing really ground breaking or complex. The story goes generic otaku male gets killed in world X and ends up in world Y. Then he just proceeds to make life better for its people in his own fashion.
Art:
 Generic late 2010's art style with thin outline and vibrant colors
Sound: 
VA's are on point, the sound effects are average at best. While the music (besides the END) is very generic and unmemorable. 
Character: 
This MC is the Exact opposite of Ainz Ooal Gown. and while still being powerful, Unlike AInz he has no skill, training, or mastery of what he can do so he getsbeaten when he doesn't use his ability to just eat everything.\n\n
Enjoyment: \n
This anime is the like a lighter version of Gate (or a mature version of Pokemon). Lots of Cute moments, some sexy moments and a decent amount of fighting.\n\n
Overall: \n
This anime isn't some great and new but it has just enough in the right areas to make it a fun watch.

In case you couldn't tell from the "episodes seen" section above, this review is written as of 12 episodes of the show.
Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken, or That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime, is a 25 episode show of the isekai(another world) genre that began airing in the Fall 2018 season. Isekai are very widespread at this point, having done both amazing and terrible things. It's reached a point where the genre doesn't have anything new to do but creatively twist upon the tropes of it's base concepts, and this is one such show.
Our main character, Rimuru Tempest(as mentioned in the synopsis above)has been reincarnated as a slime in a fantasy world after being murdered in his previous life. Slimes - also commonly called ooze - are common types of monsters in many fantasy roleplay games. True to their name, they don't usually have any distinct shape and appear as large masses of gelatinous fluid. Rimuru has multiple special abilities, one of which allows him to absorb things to gain more skills. After arriving in this new world, ends up becoming the leader of a goblin village in trouble with Dire wolves, and after solving their problem continues to work with them to increase their strength and resources, as well as possibly become a full fledged nation. Rimuru and the goblins slowly continue to make allies throughout the course of the story. Towards the latter half of the first cour(12 episodes), an army of approaching orcs is introduced as an impending threat. \n\n
While entertaining, with an amazing first episode, I could help but feel that it was lacking. The plot is fine, the sound is good(though it's not anything that I'd want to listen to outside of the show),  while mostly average, the animation has its standout moments, and the supporting characters are entertaining enough with some decent comedy, but Rimuru as a character is inherently bland, lacking in enough overall presence(besides the story's focus on him) that he could have easily been a member of the supporting cast, with one of the more interesting members of that roster replacing him as the main character. Rimuru simply hops through the story almost without a care in the world, with only occasional moments where he seems to even have desires as a character, otherwise being a near personality-less blob that occasionally attempts to be goofy. The character is written as your standard "good guy" with almost no extra effort put in.\n\n
Entertainment value is still present, and this show definitely isn't a waste of time. However, if you have other things you could be doing, or other shows that you're watching, I'd recommend holding off on this one for a bit.

I watch a lot of Isekai anime,
most of them are pretty entertaining and all, but not every aspect of an anime I watched took the cake as I stumbled apon THIS little treasure as a manga.
The moment I learned, that it was airing in the Autumn Season, I couldn't wait for it to air.
I love the artstyle of ALL characters, even if I wished, that Shion was still her old self (I mean, BOI she HOT) and also the story is 1 to 1 taken over, which ALWAYS IS a big (+) in my books. So far, even the opening "Namless Story" catches you andtakes you right into the journey of Rimuru.


And also Tate no Yusha. THESE both Anime actually are not just RUNNING the Isekai stories, they'll be called its flagship.


I mean "Yeah, we had SoA (kinda sad I mentioned it) and Lost Horizon. But Tensei shitara Slime Datte Ken actually adds so many more things, as all the pretty mediocre stories we seen so far. 

It has politics, alliances, the utopia it is creating, while also holds you on to your seat, while it catches you and is kidnapping you in to the this well crafted world of an isekai anime. 


The story is funny, kinda sad, dramatic, while also it has this "overpowered" character, who is actually not really overconfident in his unique skills, also somehow manages to be adorable and incredible good. Rimuru remains alsways be as "calm" and "collected", while even can be sometimes pissed at something. 


This is a really good Isekai Story, very well crafted. And EVERYTHING fits so well. EVERYTHING. And I mean EVERYTHING.

To put it simple: Mindless fun.
 Don't think too much while watching this, otherwise you might realise the characters are as generic and bland as it gets (Gabiru is HONESTLY the best character so far, Gobta and the dwarf are also decent, but they don't get enough screentime) and the story and worldbuilding is just an agglomerate of ideas a 9yo has.
 But the main problem is the pacing, that is something that just can't be overlooked like the rest. It is painfully slow. 
Art and sound are good.
 Nonetheless, it's quite enjoyable, they give us new characters constantly (which is both good and terrible),fun fights, some funny moments and boobs.\n\n
Seven/10. \n

It has been great for now, no stupid harem, no over-convoluted plot, just a guy reborn as a slime and now exploring the new world.
The character is likable, the story is doesn't take itself seriously and Rimuru is super fun as a main character, very funny and innocence. I really like that he didn't immediately find a human as a first friend when he was being reborn as a slime, because that wouldn't make sense.
What I don't like is the ost, or lack of ost, some of the scene barely has any background sound or music which will make it feel a bit bland. 
Overallit is a very relaxed and chill story. Lets hope it won't change for the worst, best anime this fall. Welp, there is Seishun Buta Yarou wa Bunny Girl Senpai no Yume wo Minai  and new Jojo. Other than that this is the best.

Long time since I write a review. To put it as simple as possible, this is the best anime in its genre I have seen in a long time.
Very refreshing after 3 seasons of Overlord for instance. Whereas Overlord is riddled with evil characters doing evil things and you are directed to see them as the main characters, in TenSure you have a really powerful reincarnated character, using his powers to do Good and not Evil, as in Overlord.
The characters are lovable so far, and well written to boot. The plot seems solid and progressing strongly, and I really look forward to every episode, andgladly we know it will have 24 eps, so they will have time to develop the story (or not...who knows) and we can have more of its weekly enjoyment.


Art is not overwhelming but the story does cover for it completely. 


Now I will see its manga for sure


All in all a really nice series !

Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken is as flawless as an anime can be.
The isekai genre has been overpopulated in the past few years but in certain cases an Isekai can be gold and that's the case with this anime.
I like this show because it's story is simple but well thought, it's art is not the most beautiful but it fits with the story, it's music is good and fits well in the moments it plays and it's characters are amazingly well developed.
The things that i like the most about this series is the great animation along with the ounstanding enjoyment that it gives me butmore imoortantly is that this is greater than the sum of it's parts.



AOTS FALL 2018.

This anime is one of the those animes that features an overpowered main character showing off his overpowered skills to those around him. Watch this anime if you want to sit still in awe on your chair because of how intensely overpowered the main character is in this show.
I've read a few comments that said this show was boring. I think someone who has watched too much action anime recently and is looking for something that is more different from all the other animes that features OP MCs might say it's boring. Not only that, but it sort of gives the feeling of being insidea RPG game which many other anime produced nowadays also gave off.  Yup, it's an isekai anime with an overpowered MC - we actually see that very often nowadays.


But these are the points that I want to commend the anime of:

- the pacing is just right. The art doesn't falter throughout the episodes so far. Nothing feels sped up. Everything is smooth. What more can you ask for for a high-quality animation? It's worthy of getting 24 episodes.

- the anime has rendered the manga very well. A good anime producer will make a product more entertaining and worth spending time for than the actual manga. I haven't read the manga, but I just seem to end up thinking that the anime has made the story more entertaining by the qualities which mangas can't have: moving images, sounds, and speaking characters.


Whether it's entertaining or not is relative. But if you are not one of the people who might think it's boring according to what i've said before in this review, maybe you'll be entertained.


You have to want to watch action to enjoy this anime. If action to you right now sounds like meaningless movements back and forth then don't watch this. There are indeed episodes that don't feature action so don't get me wrong - it's not only about fighting, it's about how far the MC's influence in this isekai spreads (to me at the moment that is in episode 9). You end up wondering how far the MC will go in this isekai world with his powers - as a slime of course!


Story: 10/10, Art: 10/10, Sound: 10/10, Character: 10/10, Enjoyment: 10/10, 

Overall: 10/10 or 9/10

This review is heavily based on personal opinion and may feel biased (which I don't disagree if you say so), feel free to agree or disagree.
Story: 9/10
Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken (or Tensura for short) is a fantasy setting anime that manages to separate itself from any other generic fantasy shows that the anime industry has. The story follows a 37 years old virgin that died defending his co-worker from a (potentially) jealous assailant. Then he got reincarnated, but rather than being reincarnated as a human, he got reincarnated as a Slime. The part that really separates itself from any other generic Isekai (another world)genre shows is that the protagonist isn't a teenager, but a fully grown adult man which defines how he acts and reacts  compared to things around him. I wouldn't continue this part as it will get into some spoiler stuffs. The story never takes itself too seriously, putting gags here and there but never takes the jokes too far either.


Art: 9/10

The art and animation of Tensura is just... amazing and jaw dropping even. The vibrant colors, the smooth animation, everything just clicks. I can really tell that this show is made with love and care from it's creators.


Sound: 9/10

The sound design is amazing, the Slime sound effects, etc etc. I don't really have much to say since I'm not really a master when it comes to sound design.

The Opening and Ending song however, is just fantastic. Especially with the Ending, rather than making you rest after the episode to the point where you are just bored with the Ending song, it makes you hyped for what it has to offer next, which is rare considering that this is an Anime Ending.


Character: 9/10

As I said before, the fact that our main character Rimuru is previously a full grown adult man really changes the story. And the people (most of them are monsters but don't worry about it) really feels like actual people (except for some that is) while making us not forget that this show is goofy and cartoonish, which is impressive considering that many anime takes itself too seriously to the point where we just can't enjoy the show anymore.


Enjoyment: 10/10

The fact that not only the show perfectly adapts the source material to another medium, but also improves it, really makes me love this show. I had high hopes when it was announced and my hopes were answered, I got more than I wished for.


Overall: 10/10

Tensura is a comedic and cartoonish Isekai fantasy show that manages to put a spin to the genre by being really good and enjoyable.

The 8 episodes that have aired up till now, I can safely say that Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken is one of the best anime this year. 
Why I say so? 
First things first. This is an isekai. The bad reputation that isekais have gained over the years with a few exceptions,can surely be overlooked in this anime. Why? WHERE HAVE YOU EVER SEEN A PERSON GET ISEKAIED AND TRANSFORMED INTO A F***ING SLIME. 
But in all seriousness this anime deserves a watch. And here's why...
CHARACTERS:
The characters in tensura are absolutely amazing and have an altogether unique characteristic of their own. The MC, our favoriteRimuru is just about the best MC this season (Only if it weren't for Sakuta from bunny girl). He is absolutely the type of character that the fantasy isekai genre is in dire need of (Disregarding sora & shiro, my favorite characters of all time). Rimuru is the major attraction of tensura. Well obviously because he is the slime but even so. But other than Rimuru, the goblins are just amusing (Gobta is love). \n\n
PLOT:\n
The plot, honestly, until now hasn't been a really intricate one. But seeing the OP and the ED and also from the Manga readers, I can surely say the plot is gonna take an amazing turn by the 12th or the 13th episode. Gotta wait about a month for that though.\n\n
MUSIC:\n
The OP isn't so great as many other anime's but I have been addicted to it quite a while now. The general soundtrack is good though. It matches the mood of the anime pretty well.\n\n\n
Overall what I can say is that ever since I had taken a break from watching anime for about a month, this anime was pretty much enough to get me hooked and right back on track.

As of writing this review only 6 episodes of Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken are out and this review will most likely change later on.
Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken was a fun little thing one of my friends introduced to me. Though carrying a lot of the isekai-cliches it manages to create an original story which kind of resemble Overlord in the aspects of interacting with the world, learning, and creating and strengthening your society. 
Story: The story goes about it mostly like other isekai shows, with the hero/heroine waking up in an unfamiliar world, EXCEPT, he's a slime. He has some basic, but powerfulabilities and a steap learning curve. The story moves slow, making 1 episode only contain a little, but at the same time makes everything light hearted and fun.\n
Pace: Since the pacing as of yet is so slow (I kind of like it) I am putting this as the biggest potential downfall of the story since, really, at 1/4 of the expected airing it still hasn't really gotten far. I'm afraid the this promising show might screw up the pacing, going too slow in the beginning, and then rushing to the end.\n
The soundtracks are excellent and I didn't find the opening and ending songs annoying, like I find most.\n
There isn't that much development of the characters as of yet, as it has only just begun, but what's there is pretty solid.\n
Summary: It's good story with a good beginning for its characters, which moves slow. I hope they get the pacing down right and think that, if the pacing ends up too slow in the beginning, that they make it longer, either through more episodes in the current season, or by making more seasons. I think extending the show would be of much more benefit for both the producers, the show and the people watching it, as I can see it becoming a popular anime.

That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Snoozefest
The first handful of episodes actually set up a really promising start to a potentially groundbreaking isekai. It's also the only anime where a tsundere dragon gets vored by a slime, so I definitely have to give it credit for that.
However, as the show enters the 10+ episode mark, a critical issue becomes apparent. This issue is the fact that the show's writers don't care about the new side characters that are introduced for Rimuru to help with, yet at the same time expect us to care. For some unexplainable reason, the show decides to have some genericshonen fights, perhaps in an attempt to get some free publicity from "Epic Anime Fight Scene Complication #12 2019" on YouTube. Yet nothing about these fights is epic. There are no stakes, no "wow" moments, no memorable punches...they're just sort of there. 


By the end of the series, I really didn't care about what Rimuru was going to do to save the day this time. The fun that was present in the beginning of the series had pretty much diminished as it churned out tropes that could probably be found done better in fantasy shonen from a decade ago.


Despite my harsh criticism over the overall atmosphere/my enjoyment of the series, there are redeemable elements that belonged in a better series. Rimuru is a bit overpowered, but overall a good character. Shizue, the goblins, the wolves, Millim - all of them could've set the ground for a really good fantasy series.


The best way to describe Slime overall is "so close, yet so far." In the development of the series, an essential checkmark was clearly missed before releasing it: "isn't freaking boring."

I feel like the 1st quarter or half of Reincarnated as a Slime was good and I thought it would go somewhere but man it just turned into nothing real fast. I think this was good until the end of the battle with the huge pigs. After that I dunno wtf happened, instead of amping up the story and action everything became meaningless.
This show is still good it has all the characters and world you could want in a show, also a lot of creativity and i'm hoping season 2 will get a little more serious. That's the only thing Slime needs is a seriousarc to take it to the next level. I mean we got some serious side story on episode 24 with Shizu-san, if the whole show took that tone it would be a 10 out of 10 master piece but instead we need to focus on these little kids and meeting demon lords that are all talk and no action. There's all these demons that chat and sip wine in their mansion but why don't we see them do anything? Who knows but that's why I'm hopeful for season 2.

Welcome to my review of the anime 'Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken", often also just called "the Slime anime". This anime is produced by the studio 8bit and it consists of 24 epsidoes, originally 25. The last episode became a special which I am also talking about in this review at its end. The studio 8bit is more or less unknown and rarely comes to attention with a great anime title, if at all. Only three anime they previously did have recognition in the anime community; those being Infinite Stratos, Rewrite, and the most known of all three, Grisaia no Kajitsu (Fruit of Grisaia). Thispretty dry track record might end now. Studio 8bit might find themselves on more contracts after they landed a massive hit with 'That time I got reincarnated as a Slime'. Slime has become a save watch for the last two seasons it aired. Mostly everyone watched this show and just as many praised it. But is the praise justified or this just another overhyped anime title like many others before? 



Story/plot: Before saying anything, let start with that this anime is an Isekai. I will trust you that you know what that word means in this community. The story starts with Mikami Satoru, a regular everyday nice guy who just happens to get stabbed in the back by a robber out of unfortunate events. What continues is Satoru being reincarnated as a Slime in a Fantasy World. It starts in a cave where he gradually evolves by absorbing and killing various things and creatures. At one point it ends up meeting the storm dragon Veldora who is locked in that cave thanks to a spell. The Slime and the Dragon Form a friendship and give each others names. From then on they are Veldora and Rimuru Tempest. And from that day on Rimuru ends up helping others and bukding up relationships with other creatures.

So what is this anime about? To steal the words of others I say "This is not an Isekai, this is Civilization The Anime". And truly, the anime actually feels more like a civilization building game than an Isekai anime. Even past the civilization point Slime Datta Ken is surprisingly tame when it comes to the themes. Don't get me wrong, there is violence! But the theme and atmosphere of the anime is more or less very friendly and upbeat; something rare these days.


Art: The artstyle of Slime Datta Ken is very soft and light. The surrounding and background have a watercolor vibe to them. The characters also look pretty decent. Fighting animation was throughout the show really solid and sometimes even high quality. I don't remember the show dropping in quality at any point but I could have missed it.


Sound: Openings and Endings were solid, the ending more than the Openings. As far as my personal taste goes both the second OP and ED were the better ones. BGM was also solid but nothing stuck with me. SFX were of course there but I don't remember anything worth noting.


Characters: There are a lot of characters. A lot. Listing everyone is a bit tiring and most of them aren't worth even mentioning. The one and only one worth mentioning is the main character itself, Rimuru Tempest. Carried over from his past life Rimuru still has all his emotions, memories and self. Through these we learn Rimuru's personality. A fellow who likes peace and dislikes conficts and problems. All in all every character is fairly plain and easy constructed. Slime Datta Ken is not a deep anime do it does not need deep anime.


Enjoyment & verdict (of the main show): I'd say I overall really enjoyed the anime and it was a fun and cool ride. Slime is not the next big thing but it does what it does right. Being a nice more relaxed show is a good change for once. Now do I recommend it? Yes, I would say I recommend it as it is a nice show to watch and for what it does it's a good show. I give this anime an 8/10.


OVA verdict: Nice finisher for the show but overall unimportant and only slighly funny. If you have the time you can enjoy this last last episode, otherwise you are not going to miss anything amazing or groundbreaking.


And that's it for my review, I hope you liked it and I will see you in my next review!

Fall 2018 and winter 2019 feature a number of isekai(-ish) adaptations, like Goblin Slayer or Shield Hero, with a strong fan base behind them due to popular manga or light novels. Tensei Slime also belongs into this category, however this anime sets itself apart from the competition with one distinct feature – it is a damn good and entertaining adaptation. The studio even manged to sneak some memes into it.
SCORE: Good - 7
STORY:	Entertaining but repetitive.
As usual for the isekai genre our protagonist is granted a second chance in a fantasy world filled with magic, monsters and game-like systems, instead of eternal afterlife. The catch –main hero is a blue blob, a slime. And this concept works, because there is no world apocalypse to stop or girl’s heart to conquer, at least for now. This is basic escapism with focus on entertainment.

Narrative puts Rimaru in center of outcasts and follows his selfless task to create a peacefull community. This journey is defenitely a fun watch. There are several problems though: all the different story arcs have similar structure and become repetitive after a while: new faction is introduced -> initial conflicts arise -> big battle -> troublemakers are defeated, moderate parts join Slime-sama and get an upgrade. The show peaks midway during the orc invasion arc and cannot infuse its story with new ideas, tension or excitement afterwards. 

Pacing is like a boulder rolling down a hill. Early episodes can be considered as slow, but they do a great job at introducing the viewer to characters and world with its mechanics, while you crave for more when end creddits roll. As the story progresses, pacing becomes faster and faster; episodes in the second half turn into random events loosely hold together, not a cohesive story with a hook for more slimy content.

The way characters are treated fuels this displeasure further. 


CHARACTERS: A one slime show.

Slime-sama is an OP character, he will solve every problem with ease, win every battle and befriend everyone, but does not necessary take the good karma option on every occasion. Blue blob just enjoys his newfound life and does whatever he wants. The show also manages to transfer his joy, optimism or euphory onto the viewer. As an escapism power fantasy projection, this character works exceptionally well and fulfills its purpose.

Rimaru collects countless colorful followers. Each time a new group is introduced, those new characters will get a short backstory and a name to segregeta them from faceless redshirts. Fullstop. Expect no further development, as focus shifts with each new arc, older characters have to move to the background and remain frozen in the established master – subordinate relationship, thus there are no deeper character arcs or any development. Furthermore, this is a one man (slime) show, because everyone else is a support character and is defined through interactions with Rimuru. The show could use at least one character, who walks besides Rimaru, not behind him. 


ART & ANIMATION: I could not imagine a blue blob could look this good. 

This show looks good. Character models are detailed, colorful, interesting and stay on model for the entire run; backgrounds utilize a washed-up art style, but can express enough diversity, detail or create beatiful vistas and fit nicely into the slime world. 

Animations are crisp and enhance not only fights, but also mundane everyday scenes. Slime itself looks especially gorgeous with funny grimaces or little details, like dog ears and tail attachements when Rimaru transforms from wolf into a slime in ep2. Kudos to the animators. This is how you fill a seemingly expressionless character with charisma and offer an upgrde from paper onto blue screen, I am looking at you Edgelord Bones & Goblin Scrappypants. 


SOUND: Applause to all voice actors.

OP, ED as well as background music are nothing extraordinary, especially the later one is entirely unnoticeable. 

On the other hand, all the voice actors did a fantasic job and filled every character with soul and joy. It is obvious how much fun people had during recordings and this positive atmosphere is transferred directly into the characters and finally the viewer.


Tensei Slime is a prime example how a show can be, if everyone gives their best. Sadly, even the best production team cannot go beyound the boundaries set up by its source material.

It has definitely become a religious offering for every season to have “THAT” one Isekai that will have a good percentage of the fandom's following no matter how trash it is, in the food industry, that would be where McDonald's ranks up with, something very familiar that's easy to get into with a very simple to grasp concept that remains very true to the “modern” reception of Anime. Unfortunately, “Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken” matches up with everything mentioned above, however, as unexpected as it is, the trashy part couldn't be more wrong.
On the surface, “Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken” seems like your type ofIsekai where your virgin pervert dude is thrown into a cursed land, along with his magical weapon and a shallow cast of females that form his harem save the world and live happily ever after. “Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken” has so little in common with your average Isekai and so much more with a world-renowned RPG game with a Skyrim-like depth in both worldbuilding and event handling making every episode more of a save checkpoint that bit by bit get you closer to the end game filling you with a great sense of achievement at the end of your journey.



Story (8/10):

Trust me, as generic and boring as it might strike you, it does get a whole lot better. Of course, every Isekai starts the same, the protagonist has to enter a new world after they either die or just give up on their world, sometimes it's just mandatory and doesn't give the said protagonist a chance to decide, but that's irrelevant to this.

You have this relatable middle-aged dude, somewhat of a capable gentleman of the working class that's just fed u with how he's living, suddenly surrenders his life to save an acquaintance of his, next second he's in another world that screams of RPG, but this time, it's neither an attractive shallow handsome-head that gets all of them hoes neither a powerhouse badass edgy rascal that gets his victory on demand. He just gets reincarnated... as a... S-Slime. I swear I wasn't going for the pun.


The plot runs through speedy pacing that really does justice to its short self-contained arcs. There is a lot of action and also a balanced amount of dialogue that serves a great deed into building the world around the characters making them feel like an ant, something very insignificant against a much greater entity, but that doesn't limit from their influence.



Art (8/10):

If Anime could get sick, one of those devastating plagues would be the lack of inconsistency visually speaking. Some of the fights, not, let's say, all of the fights look outstanding, almost breathtaking with smooth cartography and slick camera movement.

On a general note, the show does have a noticeable almost warm visual effect layered on everything that makes everything look more greenish and natural that emphasized the medieval theme that houses the event of the story. The colors look bright and attractive while still easy to keep up with the action.

The anatomy is one other thing I feel they've done right, there is something about it that just screams of RPG, everybody looks like a heavily customizable NPC from a Bethesda game.



Sound (8/10):

Voice acting wide, I can't really complain about anything while still can't find something to really praise that much, it felt decent, just above average at best, probably the ridiculous of high voices wasn't my cup of tea, but I really have to give it to the sound effects and the background soundtracks, oh, just so good, and you know how much cool abilities from magic to an ever more magical kind of magic, vocally simulating those can be a real challenge but the team behind this side of the show knew what they were doing, straight out of a quality AAA title.

I can spit it the way I have it on my mind, but it's something very satisfying that highlights those short but yet powerful fire burst sound effects.

The soundtracks were really amazing as well, as you'd grown on them on your favorite RPG, the same was here, you could swear you've had countless hours of fun while watching and paying attention to them like you would do when playing a video game.



Characters (7.5/10):

I can't stand for the show and say it had anything revolutionary regarding its character cast if anything, that was a HUGE roster to keep track of. And I'm not kidding, a tremendous amount of new faces make it to the screen every arc, and no, they stay there until the last episode, with is one plus point for not neglecting any characters. Take some notes, Naruto.

It feels really bad to not give off a slightly higher score on this pick, but I got to really take out my frustrations on some boring and badly written characters that are just there for the same of filling a character spot. Yes, talking about you, Milim, if that was how your correctly spelled and I'm not bothering to check, that's how much I care.

A wide selection of characters are just there as an image of what it's supposed to be a powerhouse, but having a shallow childish figure hold a great title of power and following while being easily swayed by a gram of honey, Nah, that sounds like a wasted potential on a stupid loli from me.



Enjoyment (9/10):

You can imagine the satisfaction I got after every achievement done by the protagonist, as he's narrating what he's going through, you really feel like the person with the controller at hand doing everything yourself, starting off basically from scratch, literally, just a piece of moving slime with no primitive senses or anything to making it into a badass ruler that can start blad thunderbolts with a rise of a finer, just how badass is that?



Overall (8.1/10):

I really, really recommend this pick and even dare to recommend it to people that are not into Isekai because it truly does offer a unique experience that a lot of other similar shows fail to deliver upon. It's got likable characters, pacing fast enough to keep the action good and the excitement high all the time, and of course, it's got a lot of hype surrounding it.

Episodes 1-23:
Probably one of the best "healing" anime I have ever seen. I would even call it a slice of life of fantasy isekai animes. That being said, the characters are rather shallow, also the behavior of the reborn protagonist doesn't really fit his previous life, but who cares? After a while the main theme becomes kind of repetitive, but is still enjoyable and it fits the "healing" genre. Also the final arc didn't really fit the previous parts - for some unexplained reason the author decided to completely change the aim of the protagonist and kind of cut away from all of the previousdevelopment, which is a let down, because it means there couldn't really be any grand ending, cliffhanger or anything similar. Manga ends here at this point.


Episodes 24-25:


Putting opening, ending and 20 minutes of TV static would be more enjoyable then what they did. One looks like a sped up attempt to lure the viewer to the next series (because of the lack of anything of the sorts thanks to ending an arc at EP23 - probably the biggest mistake) and the EP25 other was replaced by OVA recap?

Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken, or from now on Slime Anime, started as your generic transferred into another world, but with a catch anime, like the dime a dozen other Isecai. This time the catch is that our MC becomes a slime of all things. Mmmokay.... Seems fair, I could watch this. 
And thankfully so, for the first 15 episodes as so I didn't regret watching it.
The MC has character, more than the average lone wolf teenager who just wants to be nice to everyone and everything works just fine for him...
Nah, our MC got his powers from a godly being, and has some stupidlybroken powers that can end all fights in 2 seconds if he wants... Wait this isn't where I wanted to go with this... Uhm...

Yes, our MC has a broken ability as mentioned that lets him get stronger by each confrontation he passes. But in all honesty, this is not something that damages the show's enjoyment factor like some other titles in the genre. Why? Because again, the MC has character. You can relate to him. Or something like that...

The first few episodes focuses on character and world building, which is nice, then concludes in a smaller fight sequence. Yay! Action. However, the show’s most enjoyable part (in my humble, yet insignificant opinion) starts after these episodes, where it becomes some sort of Sims city, the anime, fantasy edition, where we get to see MC progressively build a community of all the characters that gets introduced one by one in the following episodes in a way where every character has its own place in the community, yet the older characters to which we get to love doesn’t get forgotten, they are always in their place. THIS made me really like Slime anime. Each faction that gets integrated to this community has its own little arc, but the older ones never get in the shadow of the new members. (I’m repeating myself, am I?) I also have to mention that there is one person, who similarly has her own small arch of integration who I dislike to a degree, due to her little pinky haired destructive nature that has no place in the story what so ever because her voice and looks and personality is annoying as heck and I hate her and I despise her and…… ok, I’m calm now…

Anyway, the world building in this anime is really taught trough so for that only reason I recommend you, oh thy reader of my humble review, to watch Slime anime.


HOWEVER…. After the last “community building arch” Slime anime becomes something that I would moderately describe as a waste of time. Remember that lovely community that we saw developing with craft and care, housing countless character that are enjoyable and lovable (except you pinky hair)?

You better forget them, cuz you never see them again in this season. What we get is our MC wandering off to “I don’t care about this place” kingdom because apparently there is some business there with some characters we never met, and probably not worth switching with THE ENTIRE SET OF CHARACTERS we get to know. Other than MC and his loyal companion doggo, nobody gets to do anything ever again from the old set. Remember when I said that the old characters were introduced in a way, one by one that the older ones don’t get out shadowed? This is the complete opposite of it…


And the problems are not just with the last episodes… 

There are huge problems with the pacing. Each ark has its own mini events. We get introduced to the problem, we get to meet the new characters, we get to know their backgrounds, and then we get to know about the impending doom approaching our beloved community. We think of a solution but the uncertainty is always lingering in the backgrounds not knowing if the city of the Slime god, all hail thy will gonna survive or going to be reduced to ashes and salt. Then… big baddie of the arch is defeated in half an episode… Really?

Sooo…. Art and sound is okay. Don’t ask me about OP and ED because I skip them always… aaand with that should be it.


TL.DR: Good characters, great first half, mehish second half, horrible pacing,

Recommend watching it.

That Time I Got Reincarnated As A Slime is not your average isekai. For further proof just read the name again. On first glance, a show where the main character is a slime doesn’t sound all that interesting. I mean there is only so much a ball of gelatinous ooze can do. Yet this show somehow pulled it off and became one of the most beloved anime’s of the year. 
One thing I love about the story for Isekai Slime (I’m too lazy to write out the whole name) is how our main character becomes a slime in the first place. The way the worldgrants him these powers makes sense based off the situation that he finds himself in in the first episode. Now that he’s a slime he should be really weak, but once again because of how the story establishes the world, when our slime boy uses his form to become OP it makes sense. His greatest power however is the power of friendship and before you stop reading in disgust let me explain why it’s the best thing to happen to this show. By our MC befriending everyone we get to watch the world grow, and see characters that we would normally despise come into their own. It’s very refreshing to see a story truly value all of its characters rather than use them as fodder for our MC to show off. Instead our slime boy allows others to take the spotlight. 


The art and animation for this show is pretty good. From what I could see, most of it was drawn in 2D with just a splash of cgi here and there but it never distracted me from what was going on. Opening and ending songs were kind of meh but that’s just me. The one thing I disliked was how the show teases future events in the opening song. It’s not that it spoils anything, but it can be frustrating to see events that are a long way off from happening. 


Overall, this was a surprise for me. I didn’t know watching an isekai about a slime could be so enjoyable and refreshing. So if you are looking for something different among the constant wave of isekai fanfare or are just looking for a wholesome feel-good fantasy then consider giving this a watch.

First of all, certainly this is not the best anime by any mean far from it actually.
However Tensura is still a nice, heartwarming anime series to watch.
The adaptation feel alot better than may LN anime adaptation for example Sword Art Online Alicitzation which is also airing at the same season as this anime. 
Tensura do a got job at pacing I think . Not many important detail skipped.
This series is not an intense action series, or Drama, so If you looking for an intense battle scene, or drama or romance I suggest look for something else. Tensura is more like a slice of life withbattle sometimes at least in Tensura S1\n\n
As such I like the character in Tensura very much especially the side character. Because their interaction and development is very amusing to watch. I enjoy my time watch this series just because it is fun, light and help me a lot to relax.\n\n
Again this is a very chill series with some world building, and heartwarming moment. It is not action anime, drama, romance, or something tense. There is no world to save at least for now, just a slime want to make a place to live happily with his friend. So do not take it seriously. In fact they never too tense. It is like you expect anime like non non biyori to be intense.\n\n
If you are looking for a slice of life series just to relax after working I suggest give this a chance.\n

THIS REVIEW IS NOT SPOILER FREE
