 So this story begins with slime, no wait it begins with a middle age man who dies and reincarnated as slime in other world and finds a dragon then  devours it and then some other creatures and gains their powers and then protects a goblin village from wolfs I think  and then give names to them and then protects few adventurers  and then devours a girl and then makes some friends from a capital who are blacksmiths then makes some more friends with thorns on their heads and give names to them too and then helpsthem to defeat some pigs and then become chums with those  pigs  and then give names  to them too and then becomes friend with an airhead demon loli and then defeats some monster and then protects some child .

 THE END


So to sum it up it is all about naming monsters and becoming friends.

This show as a whole has been an absolute blast. Remembering back to when it was announced about a year ago now and I'd never even heard of it before to now being so immersed with the novels, manga, and anime is crazy to think about. I probably wasn't the biggest isekai person beforehand but slime, along with others, helped me be more open to them. This whole season has been a joy really. I've enjoyed pretty much all of it. 
Rimuru and the cast were great with how fleshed out and diverse they all are. Rimuru being able to bring all different creatures togetherin an island of misfit toys kind of way was very endearing. From Gobta to Benimaru to Milim to Shion, loved em all. Not a too many characters I disliked. Seeing Rimuru grow his influence and footprint in the world has been really fun. I think that's what sums this show up best, Fun. Cause it's just plain old blast. A Saturday morning cartoons kind of feel to it. Goofy at times sure and the pacing goes up and down but just........fun. 


A good ole fantasy adventure which I can appreciate when it's done so well and with so much passion. I truly think that 8bit put their best into this. Adaptation flaws aside I believe it was done with passion just like the source. The action always looked sharp with all the big scale set pieces that happened. From a technical aspect it was really good. Big bright and welcoming. Music was great too. The


Overall this is without doubt one of the best isekai out there. High on stakes and gravitas, no. But fun as hell and a good time, unquestionably. 


9/10


See you next year Rimuru!!!

I feel like sometimes we are scraping the bottom of the barrel for Isekai ideas...well that is if you only watched the first couple of episodes. Don't get me wrong, the whole genre feels really over saturated at this point but it is a really popular genre+. But you do get some that stand out from the heap and have some very intriguing aspects. So take this anime for example. Another standard fantasy isekai anime but the protagonist is instead a creature that is considered weak by fantasy standards. But then you realise that is not enough so you have to think of something. Thenyou have an idea, how about make it the anime equivalent of Civilisation. 



Sit back, relax and be friends with Ghandi because he has all of those nukes as a I present to you the anime review for That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime. Lets begin. 



Story: 6.5/10


We begin with seeing a middle aged business man by the name of Satoru Mikami getting stabbed by a random assailant and is bleeding to death. With his friend by his side, he tells him that his final wish is for him to destroy his hard hard drive on the computer (clearly a man who has correctly prioritised his wishes). Instead of passing to the great beyond though, he finds himself reincarnated as a slime. Trying to figure out where he is, running into some colourful characters and given the name Rimuru Tempest. He sets out onto the new world and prepares to leave his mark on the world, whether intentional or not. 


When the first couple of episodes features a slime making conversation with a Tsundere dragon, you know you are in for something special here. And that is somewhat the case as the story goes on. The story feels like the it is split into different arcs as there always seem to be a new obstacle or threat that Rimuru has to overcome. Normally in different scenarios which is nice because sometimes you need to watch something more relaxing or something more intense and it seems to know when it wants to do a more relaxing arc or a more intense arc. Although, the more battle heavy arcs don't carry too much tension since the good guys are overpowered as f**k but it is always nice to live out a power fantasy, but that is just accepting that these guys and gals are strong. Is that a bad thing? Well the show gives us some reasons as to why some of these characters are strong or get stronger. Rimuru gains the powers of whatever he devours, so we him gain more power as he fights greater and greater threats. As for the rest of the cast, the power of the name is what gives them strength because they are given and identity rather than be some nameless monster. 


But what this show does well is it takes what is good about an Isekai anime and builds on it. Discovering a new world, meeting unique people and creatures, gaining strength over time and becoming an important figurehead of the world. But Rimuru doesn't do it by gaining strength and power, he does it by building a society of monsters. 


The overarching plot of this story IMO is Rimuru is trying to help build a society for monsters to coexist together in harmony. What starts off as uniting a tribe of Goblins with a pack of Direwolves turns into a massive community consisting of Goblins, Direwolves, Trolls, Dwarves, Orcs, Lizardmen and Dryads and living in peace together, as well as making alliances and trade agreements with neighbouring kingdoms. Rimuru doesn't simply ask or has it fall on his shoulder, he has either earn, make deals or create scenarios where it can benefit both parties. It is nice to see Rimuru simply trying to reach out instead of simply giving it to them because would you immediately make a deal with a slime? The show plays on the stereotypes of typical fantasy monsters and makes sure that the monsters are treated as equals to the rest of society by earning their respect. That what this show does well, it makes Rimuru have to earn their respect, rather than just giving it to him. 


The show narrative is enjoyable to watch...for the first half of this show. The second half is where I think momentum starts to slow down and we just get episodes that have moments but is just a load of meh. Not really exciting or emotional or tense or anything like that. While it does still have its comedy moments, the second half feels lacklustre. I put the blame on its weaker second sub plot that I will get into later on. Then it just ends, like that. Nothing to get me hyped for another season, it just ends and we're given two filler episodes to round out the show. Even the finale episode that ends the current story ends in a montage sequence for about half the episode. Talk about going out on a whimper. 



Characters: 8/10


Rimuru Tempest is indeed the main character of this show and honestly, it is nice to see an overpowered character not get everything handed to him, or her, or it. Slimes don't have genders but since Rimuru was originally a male businessman, I'll just refer to it as a male. Okay so Rimuru is, like other Isekai protagonists, a vessel used to allow us to see the world that he (as well as us) does not know about. So how do you get around doing that? Well building a society of course. Being a slime obviously has its disadvantages as slimes are considered cannon fodder enemies by fantasy standards. So when a slime is the leader of a community of monsters, well then people are just going to get confused. So Rimuru has to earn the respect of the people he comes across in order to make sure he is not some average slime. Of course his overpowered status does help but he also uses his knowledge of a businessman and thinks with a level head to get out of scenarios unscathed and benefits him and the people that serve under him. For example, when you encounter a rather chirpy daemon girl with overwhelming power, what would you do? Would you do 

a) Face her in a one on one battle. 

b) Send your subordinates after her. 

c) Make peace with her. 

d) Plead for mercy and serve her like a dog. 

If you answered any of those, you would not benefit the people you are protecting. Rimuru would rather do a bit of a) and a bit of c) so that Rimuru would get her attention but not go to far in order not to danger the lives he is protecting. He doesn't just recklessly charge in but instead assess the situation and tires to come up with a solution for any scenario. I respect that because he is thinking of the situation logically rather than just being reckless. It really does make him a great protagonist. 


The rest of the cast is vast and varied with various quirks and personalities and they are all endearing. Some fall into stereotypes but with a cast this big, I can forgive that. There are some standout obviously. Gabiru is a Lizardmen that is so full of himself as to being a great leader and great warrior that is just funny for him to get thwacked and gut punched when he totally deserves it. Millim who appears later in the series has a very nice chirpy personality and childlike wonder that acts as a wild card and a constant headache for Rimuru. Then there is Gobuta, who acts as the lovable underdog who wouldn't think would kick your ass until he does. 


There is one character in this show however that I think the show underdeveloped and that's Shizue Izawa. Despite being a main driving force for Rimuru when going forward, her overall relevance to the plot and screen time feels small despite being supposed to be a major element to the plot. Her main relevance is to give Rimuru a human form and that's really it. The whole subplot about fulfilling her final wishes is rather underwhelming and rather tedious at times. It only really comes into the final episodes of the show where she is an important factor but I feel you could have some some small rewrites and you wouldn't see much of a change. Some people might not agree with me on this point but it was a nagging factor for me. 



Animation: 5.5/10


Lets just say I'm not a big fan on the show's art style. It looks rather poor and does not look like a lot of effort was put into it. Particularly with the foresty areas where the backgrounds looked poorly drawn and was hastily put together. Some aspects and locations were slightly done better but honestly, it really does look primitive and I do not like it. Character designs are better in this regard and varied. Gobuta in particular is my favourite for its intentions. Gobuta design looks crappy compared to the others but I think that it was intentional because it hampers in that Gobuta is an underdog that doesn't look like he can kick your ass. So that is a nice touch. The animation itself fine. Sometimes the fight scenes can bring the best out of the animation but other times, it looks very meh, even cheap at times. So it can be inconsistent but it never really bothered me. Although I do like the expressions Rimuru makes which is nice since a slime doesn't really make facial expressions.



Sound: 7.5/10 


The soundtrack I would say does its job well. There always seems to be a soundtrack made for the scenario and I enjoyed it. While none particularity stand out, they definitely add to a scene. Whether it is a more calming scene, a sense of foreboding or a battle scene, there always seem to be a nice OST to compliment to a scene. 


I also particularly enjoyed the openings as well. Notice I said openings, so both of them are good IMO. "Nameless story" and "Meguru Mono" (which are both done Takuma Terashima) have good production values and does well at showing the cast and giving them a nice spotlight. Both vocal performances are also definitely good as well of the instrumentals matching the pace that the opening is trying to match. If I had to choose one, it would probably be the first one because the animation is top notch and something that the rest of the anime wishes to be like. The endings as well add are nice extensions to the openings as they act as nice closing sequences to the ending of each episode so I particularly enjoyed them. 



Conclusion: 


Slime definitely has its quirks that make it an enjoyable Isekai anime. It does stumble in some area, mainly in animation and some areas in the character department, but does have the necessary niches that make Isekai anime enjoyable and then some. The way the story progresses, how Rimuru grows his reputation, the huge cast of characters that are enjoyable in their own right for the most part and having good openings. Even the second opening stands out in a winter season that is f***ing stacked with good anime openings. Yet the show does stumble in the its major subplot and kind of fizzles out in the end, leaving to a rather unsatisfying conclusion. It left me not hyped for Season 2 of this show whereas and ending that has to be continued for another season should get me hyped.  


The appeal in Slime however, is that it takes what is good about an Isekai anime and runs with it. The power fantasy, the unexplored world, the characters you meet along the way. They are all here. And since they are all aspects I enjoyed, that should make it a highly recommended anime right? Yes and No. Power fantasy is something that only some people will enjoy and some people will criticise it. Even though the show does a good job of explaining it, it probably won't persuade people.


My Personal Enjoyment: 7/10 



Overall score: 6.9/10  Recommendation: Consider it

To be honest the amount of good reviews this anime has baffles me. It feels like an anime that was made for kids but ended up being marketed to the older fan base. I have a few but very major problems with this anime and here they are:
My first problem is with the story. The start is promising, the last word being "Erase my Hard Drive" was gold. But it takes a strange turn from there. I feel the story takes too many sharp turns to avoid confrontations because it would be a pain to resolve them. Like the part about punishing the orcs orthe absolute submissions of the wolves after their leader was killed. It's understandable why the indestructible slime has such an easy time trusting these people but there is little to no politics shown in areas where a political story line would thrive. Most moment that are supposed to be meaningful feel a little forced and therefore takes all meaning out of them. Fights for the most part are settled in the quickest way possible which usually leads to the other character submitting in fear (that seems to be intended for comedic effect but falls closer to the line of shameless), laughing as though they are some high and mighty being that approve of the little guy and are impressed by him and his potential to grow (of which we barely see any) or coming to the realization that they messed up big time and being defeated. There no sense of danger and every battle is just a wait until the MC takes on the main bad guy and defeats him, later finding some reason to forgive everyone involved in the incident as though nothing happened, a sentiment which is then also followed by everyone under his wing. Then comes the unconditional love of all creatures for a being who has named them. This is one aspect that is not further explored. The tension between characters is non existent and plagues the story, making it almost unbearable. Think about being in a room where everyone is supportive, happy, excited and jumpy but all the while giving the impression that it is all fake, that's how genuine a feeling you get when watching this anime


Next the Characters. The development of characters is one of the laziest I have seen in anime. It's not Isekai wa Smartphone bad but not impressive nonetheless. It seems as though the character just have an epiphany about how great Slime-sama is and just fall in love with him. The goblins are perhaps the only ones with a justifiable reason as to why they trust him so much: they are a weak race that found a protector. But the other races seam to just trust him because why not. The only character with an extensive backstory is the hero who only appears for a short while and is then killed off to give the MC a body. Their undying loyalty to the slime leaves little to no wiggle room for moral dilemmas or story arcs of personal growth and redemption for the other characters.  It's as though they are on the same page about everything and have no thoughts of their own, one example being how the ogres choose to forgive the orcs after their entire clan was wiped out simply because the slime said so. The uniformity of their thoughts leaves a bad taste in my mouth because in any situation it is a given that people have different opinions, one of the reasons I don't like this show as much as others. The MC seems to be too good to be relatable with. There are no impending flaws in his character as shown by his almost infinite forgiveness and self sacrifice. He constantly makes moves that would make the people rely on him more and then seems surprised as to why that happens in the first place. There is only extreme bad and extreme good with the only in between being the extreme good being influenced by the extreme bad to do bad things.


In short, if you're not looking for something to get attached to and just want a casual watch then this anime is a good place to go. Otherwise I suggest skipping it.

It was good.
Oh wait, I have to write more than that.
So SuraTen, it's a fun show about a guy who gets reincarnated as a slime. He makes some friends and they go on merry hijinks together and just have a good time. 
The story in the first half of the series was great, but then I guess they didn't realize they only had 23 episodes to work with on the main protagonist. What I'm trying to say is the pacing ramped up near the end and I felt that. But besides that, the story was pretty great, made me tear up a couple times.
Art isgreat to look at, I'd stare at the landscapes for days, honestly. But since this is an animation, there has to be good sound, right? Right. The sound mixes with the scenery pretty well. \n\n
The characters were funny and interesting when they were the main focus of the story. Then they became background characters once their arcs were resolved, except for like maybe 3. Since the story is focused on slime dude, I guess they didn't want to take the spotlight away, or something.\n\n
I really had fun watching this, it's one of the few Isekai anime I enjoy. Some of the arcs were funny, and some of them had me wondering what was gonna happen next. One of them made me cry. Just one.\n\n
Overall, isekai is still trash. But this is one of those series that will remind you that not all isekai is trash. Only a large majority. A very large majority. So grab your shovel and start digging for your perfect isekai.

Okay.. So I must admit. At first I honestly did not understand what the hype for this anime was all about. I found it mediocre at best, and often found myself not paying attention to the story. But 23 episodes in.. it kind of grew on to me. I kind of am looking forward for the next episodes now.
So, it starts off with a 37 year old man, who is perfectly "content" with his boring life going and meeting his junior. There's this weird murderer running around with a knife. While trying to save Jr. the man gets stabbed instead and his only dying wishis for his Hard disk to be wiped off completely. Anyway, he dies and the next thing we know, he's reincarnated as a slime in another world and is making friends with a dragon, killing various monsters and eating them to absorb their powers, ruling a town of goblins, also ruling direwolves, and a lot of other weird shit. 


One thing I like about this anime is that it does focus on world building and does not rush into a story line too fast (barring a few times, at least). 


All the characters are likeable (including Gabiru, yes). And the mc, Rimuru is actually really good, and not annoyingly so. Usually, a lot of do-good characters become a little annoying with their whole justice stance and lawful-good attitude, but Rimuru is still very likeable.


One thing I did not like about this anime was that it did not give time to the characters to grow on the viewers before making them disappear. And then they expected us viewers to feel something for them. 

SPOILER SPOILER SKIP THIS NEXT LINE cough cough Shizu cough cough. I personally thought they should have given her more time, because I didn't really feel for her when she died or even after that. END OF SPOILER


Also, what's the deal with Veldora? He is mentioned in, like, every other episode. But he was actually present in only the first two episodes before Rimuru ate him. When will they find out how to get him out, and what is he going to do??

I've found this anime to be absolutely delightful. Although the plot is quite simple, the adventure is interesting enough to keep your attention and always wanting to know what happens next. It is very feel good, lighthearted with a main character that is kind, altruistic, and helps others throughout, seeming to improve the lives of everyone he meets. It definitely has a lot of the feel of other anime in the isekai genre, but it seems much less intense than most and instead much more feel good. The action sequences are pretty average, but each of them are important to the development and seem worthwhile

I've written a review previously when I've first started watching the anime till episode 6.
But I just had to write another to update my point on why this anime received a 10/10 for me.
My first thoughts when I saw the trailer of the anime before it began airing was 'It's going to be another one of those *typical* Isekai animes...'
I take that back. This is a gem among the Isekai animes.
Firstly, I'd like to address the incongruous juxtaposition. How do I put it, well... The concept of the main character, a slime. It isn't exactly ironic nor oxymoronic nor paradoxical but you get the point.Using a slime as the main character and making the main character an overpowered character with seemingly limitless power is well, contradictory.


We normally see slimes in games or in anime as weak monsters. Taking a generally classified weak monster and turning it into an overpowered being surpassing even the reputably strongest of all time was a spark of creativity!


It allows many stories to be plotted, many paths and directions for the anime to develop. Naturally, people will underestimate the slime MC, Rimuru.


This allows for development and turn the anime into a pure Isekai masterpiece.


And also teaches us not to judge a book by it's cover.




Secondly, there are many routes for Overpowered MC animes. Most tend to take the 'humble MC route' with the MC doing everything behind the scenes and no one recognizing the MC except a select few. 



Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken(Slime for short) takes a similar route except that it adds in a few twists to allow it to not be one of those 'Typical Isekai Anime'.


1. Slime doesn't have an MC who is the strongest being in the world, at least not at the beginning. The anime adds in a few fillers at the beginning to showcase Rimuru's starting ability. An ability that allows him to take other monster's abilities by devouring them. This ability allowed us to see how Rimuru turned from nothing to something. Since he only had that ability in the beginning he was pretty weak until he began to devour more and more opponents and became extremely strong.


2. Slime's main character Rimuru is humble. Like alot of Isekai MCs, Rimuru doesn't want attention because less attention means less trouble. This is logical and boring therefore, the anime forcefully brings trouble to him. That way, Rimuru can develop himself, his abilities, his relationships and many more.


3. Rimuru isn't the strongest. There are characters stronger than him. In fact there are many characters that can rival Rimuru but eventually Rimuru overcame them 

(P.S He became the strongest in the end :P spoiled u)


Rimuru knows his place. If the opponent is someone beyond his level, he will use other methods to subdue his enemy be it bribery, sweet talking etc.

Like how he handled best girl Milim, loved it!



4. Rimuru is logical and wise/crafty. He respects all his opponents and friends and rarely looks down on anyone. This allows him to not underestimate his opponents and also devise strategies to minimize combat sometimes through sweet-talking. He tries to avoid fighting unless it is really necessary


5. Like every other Isekai anime, we need cool fight scenes. And Slime accomplished that no problem. 8-bit's art was great, I have no complains and the fight scenes were epic, so were the character designs I loved all the characters very much, not to mention the goblins here. They look way better than Goblin Slayer especially since there are waifu candidates amongst the goblins themselves!


6. The voice acting was exquisite, Rimuru since he was genderless also had a voice that somehow made me feel like he's half-man half-woman. Fits perfectly!

Rimuru also always sounds very playful and cheerful yet sounding wise, like he's always thinking. When its time to get serious, Rimuru's voice doesn't got full salt and commanding. Afterall, who can follow orders from someone who's screaming and not calm? The writer knows a leader has to always think things through, be calm and handle situations with the best possible method.

Other character's voice also fit their personality very very well, for example Hakurou, the old man's voice also had a cool tune to it! The anime even took a new high when it somehow also fitted the character's faces. That's no easy fit!


Not only voice acting, the sound effects were epic. The epic wind sound effects and blast sounds... Epic!


7. Lastly, what I love about the anime is that Rimuru despite being humble he doesn't go fully unrecognized. Unlike Saitama, when Rimuru lets say, saves a town from an attack, there will at least be one or two people that recognize his help and be grateful towards him by  returning the favor by helping him out in other aspects. This eventually let for story development and allowed Rimuru to build his own town eventually through helping strangers and befriending them.


Being humble is nice but getting at least some recognition is nicer!

Rimuru doesn't want attention so sometimes he disguises himself when he uses some of his powers to TRASH what seems like an impossible to defeat monster.


Like when he saves a kingdom from being attacked using little to no effort. The kingdom is a human kingdom so the monster that attacked, let's say a dragon is an impossible-to-defeat monster to the humans while to Rimuru, it's like fighting ants. Being the humble MC that he is, he saves the kingdom in disguise.


Despite that he still gets rewarded by certain people that saw through the disguise and are in his gratitude, helping him keep his anonymous identity whilst helping him out by returning the favor through other methods.


I love that style the anime takes and its completely different from typical Isekai animes.




Thirdly, no character break. I know animes like Overlord that went to the evil MC side by season 2, all in the name of character development and there's nothing wrong with that.

But I still like Rimuru's wise strategising, witty thinking, humorous personality and his humbleness. And till episode 12, it had only improved. He didn't change much except that he became more wise and understanding since he has since fought many battles, faced hardships and established many relationships. I love that about this anime.




Lastly and my overall opinion/conclusion. The supporting characters. In this anime, there are many characters and they all get featured multiple times each one playing a role to make story development starting from Tsundere Dragon Veldora which helped explain certain things later, Goblin Rigurd whom helped with the development of Rimuru's town, my waifu Shion that later became Rimuru's self proclaimed secretary and helped Rimuru along the way all the way till best girl and number one waifu Milim Nava that helped Rimuru protect his town, introduce Rimuru to other demon lords and also taught Rimuru some fighting techniques which was all in the name of TRUE development!


This was everything I wished for in an Isekai anime,


This was  That Time I Got Reincarnated As A Slime  .












Story - 10

Art - 9

Sound - 10 (Milim so kawaiiiiiii)

Character - 10

Overall - 10

Imagine Overlord if it wasn't stupid. That's what this anime is. Doesn't waste half a season on irrelevant character arc, and is actually fast pace. 
This show doesn't spend much 6 episodes on building story that has no impact, very enjoyable story and tells it quite nicely. The pacing of episodes are pretty good, gets things resolved within 1 - 2 episodes and continues with the story, not much time is spent on irrelevant characters who doesn't compare to the main character. 
Great art, love the opening theme song, and knows how to hook audiences and keeps the hook without letting go with boring backgroundstory

This is my 1st time in my 2 years on MAL ever writing a review. And that’s only because I’m so baffled as to how this series has been getting so much praise above other Isekai. Every issue that the anime community has with Isekai all exist, in full force, within Slime.
When this series first started I quite in enjoyed. Slimes are typically low leveled creatures in RPG games. My initial reaction to the title was that this would be a series about a man reincarnating into a fantasy world as one of the weakest creatures. Which would have been immensely interesting to see.
However, whatwe received is an overpowered MC, with no flaws, and is barely breaking a sweat surviving in a new world.


I enjoyed the first few episodes, despite the OP MC. They were very feel go and it was entertaining seeing the MC adjust to this world and meeting the creatures that inhabit it.


It doesn’t take long for this to get old though. Then you realize that the show has no conflict. Technically there is conflict within the story, but I say “no conflict” because MC solves every issue so effortlessly that it might as well not have been a problem to begin with.


I think the thing that annoys me the most is the fact that the main cast have no type of disagreements or grievances was Rimuru. Everyone just has overwhelming love for him and worships him. It’s as if he’s Slime Jesus.


I guess people like the feel good, stress free nature of the series. But You can’t keep a action series running with no tension or struggle between the heroes and villains. And it’s not like the series exceeds in animation, art, and sound. It’s all average on those fronts

Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken, also known as TenSura, is an isekai about a 
main character being reincarnated in a different world after his death.
There may be some spoilers ahead, so do prepare yourself.
I've read through the novel, and I can say that the story itself is fairly good. It doesn't suffer from many common writing problems, but the author tries to do so much to introduce different parts of the world that there may be too much information to fit into a short amount of time, and that becomes apparent in the show.
This is the problem with many of the isekais that are nowadapted into shows - they were originally novels or some form of long, written literature and that is hard to convert into a video series without seriously cutting out content or spending an enormous amount of money and time.


Many characters are presented, they get their time in the spotlight, and then more characters are introduced. While it isn't a terrible enjoyment, it leaves little room for development with existing characters outside of the main few.


This show, while quite good, will suffer what I would consider "Isekai syndrome" - In the efforts to introduce a vast new world, the writer gets caught up in the details and much of the time is just spent introducing new things instead of developing what is already there, and you can see that in the show, with each new character only making a short appearance.


For those who would like an example of developing what is already there, an older example would be KonoSuba. 


While I think TenSura is certainly good, it's not really groundbreaking in the genre. It's enjoyable, there's bits of humor, you can see Rimuru's character development, but it's not anything that's going to be the new standard for the genre. Don't let this dissuade you from watching the show however - it is still one of the better shows as of late.

Well, i'm not someone you can call a hardcore anime fan, since i really got into it just a few months ago, but i think i watched my fair share of isekai to say that this is one of the best ones out there. This coming from a rookie into this world isn't really convincing but i am really having fun watching it and i think that's why we watch anime right? haha
Tensei shittara slime isn't the most exciting anime and all, but i love the vibe it gives me. It is really enjoyable seeing rimuru's village getting bigger and bigger, and all the friendsand allies he makes during his journey on this fantasy world. But even though it doesn't have a lot of fights, when we do have one, it delivers a pretty smooth animation and good coreography. 


It really doesn't disappoint technically speaking, but the strong point of it is the light and happy vibe it gives you. Never seen an isekai anime with this kind of vibe, and hope to see a lot like this in the future


9/10 definitely would recommend

(Please note there are minor spoilers in this review)
Emma Coats, a storyboard artist at Pixar listed 22 rules of storytelling on Twitter. Of those 22, one applies heavily to this anime:
"You admire a character for trying more than for their successes."
I want you to keep this rule in mind until the very end of this review. 
Reincarnated as a Slime hooked me in with a very interesting premise: the MC is reincarnated into a fantasy world as a slime (surprise, surprise). To me, this was interesting because you'd generally think that a slime is supposed to be the weakest creature in a fantasy setting, right?So how does MC manage to change anything in this world as such a laughable mob?


Here's the catch: as a slime, the MC can absorb any ability/form of any creature he digests. 


Okay, so that sounds a little OP at first, but I accepted it. Maybe there was some sort of drawback to this that the anime can throw in to really make you and MC think. And also, the opening DID immediately spoil that MC is going to get a human form anyways, basically making the idea that he'll struggle being stuck as a slime pointless... but I wanted to still give the show a fair chance.


So in the beginning, you see MC working hard to absorb whatever monsters and items he can in his initial setting and then using those new skills and items later on to assist others and himself. My initial reactions were the same as most of the other high-scoring reviewers of this show: it was cute to see everyone getting along because MC came by and started helping them with their problems. I had a grin and some good laughs along the way, too. 


I started thinking to myself: "Wow! MC is a really good hero! He's fighting for peace and helping so many people! MC is a great hero! MC is... a perfect hero. MC is perfect, like how I wanna be."


MC is perfect, like how I wanna be. 


This is where the biggest problem lies.


While it was adorable to see MC being so successful at first despite his (supposedly) limited form, that feeling quickly began to die down as the episodes ticked away. While considering the failures to successes MC has faced, you begin to realize how unbalanced the scale is in favor of his successes. MC resolves conflicts with little to no struggle; you can literally see this with how his face seldom turns into concern especially in the later episodes when they're (supposedly) fighting a formidable foe. MC's plans almost always work, and if they don't, it's because someone else screwed up rather than his plan being flawed.


Then, you begin to size up MC's relationships with other characters. NOBODY, other than the bad guys, has an issue with him. And if they do, they either get slapped silly out of a misunderstanding and end up bowing at his feet, or outright destroyed/humiliated. You even have certain female characters closely associated with MC fighting over his affection. Everybody loves MC, including one character who had his dad killed by him.


MC isn't flawed as a slime. He's OVERPOWERED as one.


MC is God incarnate; everyone bows to MC because he is capable of doing literally anything. Super strong bad guys? MC will take them out or convert them into good guys. Fatally injured good guys? MC will easily heal them back and even give them an upgrade if he hasn't already. 


The last nail to the coffin for me came at the end of Episode 13, where the viewer is presented with a shot of MC flying with bat wings in the air as he's in his human form. This scene bothered me the most because it basically encapsulated the whole problem I was having with the show now. That initial interest about how MC will survive as a measly slime? Gone, because again, he's overpowered. He even has a human form now, so what is really lost with him being reincarnated as a slime? 


Episode 14 hammered that nail down, with how MC disposed of a major foe. I won't spoil how, but this is all you need to know: there was little struggle, it wasn't a very long fight, and in the end, everything worked out for the MC and crew. I know there was one last episode of the season and there's probably more content coming afterwards. But by this point, I was done, and I doubt one more episode was somehow going to fix these issues.


It doesn't matter how good or bad you think the sound or animation is. The fact of the matter is, Reincarnated as a Slime is a power-fantasy. And that isn't a good thing for a show that sets itself up by making the MC seem like he's set in an impossible situation he has to work around. 


Still remember that quote I started this review with? Well, here it all comes, full circle.


What makes a character memorable to the most possible people is what method and how long it takes for the character to overcome an obstacle, be it a physical or emotional one. It isn't how much cool shit they can pull off while they're on-screen. It's the flaws of the character, how those flaws impact the relationships and situations the character is in, and how the character develops to fix those flaws (if he/she even fixes them at all by the end of the show/season). Reincarnated as a Slime's MC has none of that. He's already well set; he isn't scared of combat and whenever he has been so far, his fears were clearly misplaced as he's basically immortal by this point. And keep in mind, we're in SEASON ONE.


Maybe I'm judging this show too soon; maybe there is more to it that will show the MC's flaws and he'll really grow as a character. Maybe MC will face a serious challenge pushing his wits. But so far, I haven't seen any of that, not even in the art somehow. In my mind, the show has gone from: "Oh jeez, I wonder how all the characters will get out of this!" to "I wonder when MC is gonna show up to quickly fix this problem?" The stakes are too damn low and have been from the very beginning. And consequently, it creates a show with lost potential. 


Reincarnated as a Slime isn't SAO done right. It's SAO, slime-boy edition (minus the gaming).


Interesting original concept, poorly executed to keep any serious interest. 


5/10.

*mild SPOILERS ahead*
Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken or That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime, is your typical Isekai anime/manga in the sense that it takes someone, and gives them an insane OP power in a new fantasy world. What makes Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken unique however, is the idea of building relationships with people that aren't wholly dependent on the main character. It is shown numerous times that the main sub characters can look after themselves, and as such their is no need for the main character to make a harem. However, if you are into that kind of thing, a harem(esq)notion does exist - but thankfully it isn't really explored. 


The story is also pretty interesting. It may not be unique - I grant you - but it is done in a thoughtful, and in a cunning way. Without spoiling too much Rimuru (the main character), has two main objectives. First, is to make and develop her country that she found. The second being is to look after the children that her friend was looking after. What is great about this is that the story takes its time into flushing out these two objectives, making long and satisfying arcs. 


That said, their are some down sides (IMO). The first is that the fights aren't the best. Whenever I am reading the manga (and now watching the anime), I always feel that the fights are good but they could be better. The second is the animes art just isn't as good as the manga. This is to be expected, but after reading 45+ chapters, I feel that the art of the anime could have, and should have been a lot better. It's a nit pick, I know, but I feel that it is something that should be mentioned. 


Overall however, I highly recomened this show, but I implore you to read the manga, especially the short bonus stories, as they help build the world, and answer a lot of questions that I had when I was reading the manga.

The story revolves around a person who is reincarnated as a slime in a new world. At the beginning of first episode, the series gives the impression of a boring anime but progressively it gets much better and hooks you up.

Story is engrossing, each episode includes a decent progression.
character development is good. Main character is constantly evolving into something better.
Art and voice acting is good enough. Frankly I really liked the character art, especially the ogre princess pre-named. Whole characters are somewhat enjoyable
All in allit is a series quite enjoyable and worths watching this season\n\n\n

Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken is not a bad anime and is definitely not a bad story, though i do have some gripes with the way it was adapted from it source material. Just to put some problems in perspective i will compare it to another adaptation of a manga this season (I've read both and watched both) goblin slayer.
If we first take the anime in a vacuum, it an ok anime, one of those zainy shows you watch and keep coming back to even tho there is not much happening. 
The characters don't get a lot development and a re very one note, theart style, and animation is quite average. Sound is mostly fine but in my opinion Rimuru's voice makes my ears bleed every time he opens his mouth and the opening gets pretty old pretty fast.\n\n
Now the real problem i have with the anime is its pacing and this is where the comparing will start.\n
Goblin slayer adaptation has managed to cover assembling its core cast in episode 3 and moved the plot at enjoyable pace blasting through its material in a pace comprehensive to a new time watcher and very enjoyable for me.\n
In the mean time Tensei shitara Slime Datta Ken is 9 episodes deep and still hasn't started the first main arc hasn't has barley just finished setting up the premise for the big story arc and probably wont reach the manga status quo of the "village" for at least the next few episodes.\n\n
In conclusion there was never enough material for a 24 season anime and doing a one piece on it and filing the anime with hidden filler like long shots and padded conversions just ruins it for me, but you might find more enjoyment in it if you binge watch it when it finished airing coz the story is fine getting little snipits of the story every week is just tedious.

Q: How do you piss off a room full edgelords and bring out their inner BS?
A: Show them That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime.
It saddens me that apparently a lot of anime viewers have come to only want shows where killing is the answer to everything, and an omnipresent threat of death is the only form of "stakes" that they think can exist in a fantasy story.
I don't wanna get too preachy, but suffice it to say that if you're only drawn to anime for the reasons above, you won't enjoy this show. 
Yes, it's true, this anime has a ridiculously overpowered protagonist.Yes, he uses healing potions to save his friends again and again. 


If you're expecting something gritty and dark, I DON'T KNOW WHY YOU WOULD WATCH AN ISEKAI ANIME IN THE FIRST PLACE but ok look elsewhere. 


Ok, but in all seriousness, while everyone is entitled to their own opinion, I think many of the criticisms I have seen of this show are not being honest with themselves. People are saying "There's no stakes". That's not true. There are very much things at risk in every episode we watch. We'll get to that in a moment



The central argument Tensei Slime makes is as follows: If you're given vast powers, why wouldn't you use those to try and achieve world peace? If you're powerful enough that others would swear loyalty to you constantly, why not use that to build up society? 


And it turns out the way you do that isn't by killing everything in your path.


We see other characters explore this option, but Rimuru shuts it down.


People who want more death and violence out of this show are missing that very point.


"But, hsteveh" protests William Watcher, "If there's no death and violence, what are the stakes, what's the conflict?"


Oh, William. Don't you see? Rimuru isn't just trying to "beat the bad guys". Rimuru is facing down a much tougher challenge: trying to get entire communities of people to live together peacefully. The conflict often stems from character disagreements, and the mere possibility of violence and fighting. Rimuru is able to, very often, defuse these conflicts with little to minimum violence. I realize this can be a turnoff for some, but to say that it means there is no conflict or stakes is highly unfair. When Rimuru is approaching these situations, IT'S NOT JUST ABOUT WINNING. It's about if he'll be able to redeem that villian in time. Sometimes the answer is yes, sometimes it's no (see: the leader of the wolves), and very often it's "well, sort of". Our investment thus stems from Rimuru's pursuit of perfection, and the bonds that they form with the various creatures they come across. Will Rimuru be able to restrain Millim from impulse punching someone? Do we want Rimuru too? Will Gabiru learn to be less stupid? Is his father going to welcome him back? These types of questions keep us invested, rather than the soapy "OMG WHOS GONNA DIE NEXT" that 95% of shounens rely on. 



So, no, this isn't your garden variety Isekai or anime. But frankly, I like its refreshingly wholesome worldview. For once our Isekai protagonist is trying to help everyone else out and not just on a quest to get laid. For once people are acting mature and talking things out. And all of this is done while still preserving a sense of adventure. We meet fun new characters every week that are a delight to see on screen. 


Did I mention it's colorfully drawn, full of fluid, fun animation, and has some of the coolest sound effects ever in an anime? 



Haters, BTFO.

Anime Review: Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken
One of the best Isekai animes I've watched, Tensei Shitara Slime Datta Ken, or as I like to call it, Tensei Slime, is not only an action packed anime, but also a feels anime. I must say that after watching Tensei Slime, my standard of good Isekais has risen and Isekai animes have a lot of pressure to impress me in the future!
Story: As the title says, a man died and got reincarnated to a Slime. He meets a legendary dragon, and instantly becomes one of the most OP anime characters in existence. Along the way he meets countlesspeople: goblins, wolves, ogres, lizards, humans and other species of creatures and instantly gains their respect through his overwhelming power.


Story wise it is a very interesting anime as each episode presents us with a different situation and because of that, very often we are left on cliffhangers, waiting for the next episode to see what will happen next. Pacing wise I find it alright it wasn't too slow nor was it too fast it had decent pacing. Of course I might have to read the manga in order to better comment on the pacing and story but anime wise, an excellent Isekai anime!

Rating: 10/10


Animation: The animation is very detailed and very artistic. I love all the character animations and the fighting animation scenes were very well done in my opinion. 

Rating: 8.5/10


Music/Sound: Excellent OPs and EDs they were all very catchy and great to listen to. Fight and special effect sounds were also impressive to say the least I loved hearing the explosion sounds everytime there was a fight,

Rating: 8.2/10


Characters: I find that Tensei Slime shines in this category. Tensei Slime gives us detailed character development even for the minor characters and makes us fall in love with each and every character; their appearance,personality, strengths, weaknesses, character. The bond between the characters and the audience is very strong as Tensei Slime pulls no punches it shows us the ups and downs of each and every character. As for my favorite character in the series, it's none other than Rimuru! He's so hilarious and fun to watch! 

Rating: 10/10


In conclusion, Tensei Slime is an extremely solid Isekai and one which I'd recommend to people who love the Isekai genre as It has all the elements a great Isekai needs: Action packed and suspenseful storyline, excellent fights, great animation and excellent character development! I can't wait for season 2 of Tensei Slime! In the meantime I might read the manga to see what the anime missed.


Overall rating: 9.2/10

A bad case of SAO. Why? 
After a couple of episodes, it became boring and predictable. It gave us a character death that have no significant impact and basically set up a chain reaction of other connected characters that is of the same quality. However, SAO actually gave us a fright after episode 4 while Slime bored us with expositions for stuff not worth thinking over.
Now, onto a comparison with Log Horizon. LH did a better job at setting down a tone and pace while keeping the audience enraptured with its politics. It doesn't think of the audience as dumb monkeys and is more attachedwith its lores, expositions, and schemes while Slime constantly moved around stuff that have little to no impact at all. \n\n
As for the waifus? Yeah, they are there.

At its debut, this was yet another 'savior of isekai,' but why did this show just turn out OK?
Story 4 -- This show started off giving the tried and true formula of isekai the same treatment MHA gave to shounen, crossing every t and dotting every i the way we all expected but just without the bloat. For the first 13 episodes, this held pretty true and I was treated to some clean and quick isekai. It was nothing special, but the story was moving quick and it was enjoyable to see how the slime wasn't taking himself too seriously. After the midpoint, the wholeshow started to fall apart. The literal rest of the show felt like filler and not G-8 filler. The stories may be important later on in the LN, but they had absolutely no weight in the current story. Not even my general like of Rimuru could pull me through these episodes with any amount of interest. Another episode with the second half of the show is that it devolves further into the harem tropes this show originally seemed to avoid. It gets to say it isn't a harem show with how the MC isn't interested in their advances, but the way the female characters fawn over him is just the usual. \n
Art 5 -- The character designs are fun, the action for the first half of the series is genuinely good, and the backgrounds are consistent. That said, whenever CG showed up, it was Overlord III levels of bad integration. The action in the second half of the show is also noticeably less interesting in both direction and animation. Characters move less for the entire second half of the show.\n
Sound 5 -- The seiyuus give fine performances throughout the entire show. None were standout, but I could expect them to be pretty good every episode. The sound mixing and OST I can't even remember a week later. I don't think it was bad, but there is nothing to say about it.\n
Character 4 -- These characters all ended up feeling like NPCs out of a JRPG. If the characters were off screen, they could be presumed to no longer exist, since they are given nearly no characterization that is not directly relevant to how they can help our favorite slime. Only Gobta seems to get any development out of the entire supporting cast. Rimuru was fun for the first few episodes, but his shtick never changed and he turned into a one-note character. I neither know anything interesting about any of these characters nor do I want to.\n
Enjoyment 4 -- This score would have been pretty good for the first half of the show, but towards the end I started dreading watching the next episode and only watched it after I had already gotten through "Dororo" and "Mob Psycho 100 II." The only reason I finished this show was because I had some weird sense of obligation to finish what I started. I will not watch through this show again.\n
Overall 4 -- This show felt like two different shows which I would rate 6 and 3 respectively. This show was never amazing, but it had the potential to be fun the whole way through. Instead, I got bored of the show and was ready to drop it at any minute. If you want to watch just fun isekai, watch "Drifters" or "Youjo Senki." This is not a show worth recommending.

Alright imma try and ignore the little awkward teaching session that Rimuru takes at the end of the second arc and talk about the rest. I whole-heartily enjoyed Slime as I thought it was different and unique. Its hard to explain why I enjoyed it so much but the Fantasy and kinda D&D feel I got from the show was there for me. The show begins with the Rimuru gathering our first major side characters and then builds off their stories and the world around them as well as reintroducing characters seen early on again later on throughout the show. For me one the showsoverall redeeming qualities was "Great Sage" as she gets some sass later on in the show and it provides some great comedic effect. All in all this show holds an almost D&D vibe for me as well as comedy.  Although it had a bumpy part in the second arc I hope to see more adventures of our one and only Slime.

Slime Isekai, which is what i'm going to call it because of it's long title, is going to do a lot of good things for folks who enjoy isekai. However it doesn't quite rise above it's genre. And that's both a good thing and a bad thing. 
Honestly i'd heard good things about this show before I even started watching it and I can definitely see why. If you enjoy isekai and want to see something a bit more character driven and slice of lifey, then this show will be right up your alley. But if you want to see the next great isekai, I'mnot sure this is the one for that. Let me go into detail.


The story is above average. Setup is your typical isekai that focuses more on it's world building than anything else. It expands naturally outwards and it feels like the next big step in the town building is the next big step in the plot too and it all flows together quite nicely. However, this is still an isekai, and thus it has an overpowered protagonist and increasingly powerful characters. Not necessarily a bad thing, but in this case it does unfortunately evaporate the tension in some of this show's more action oriented moments. There are times the show will try to convince you of a threat or that something is 'stronger' than the protagonist, but these moments unfortunately never stick as the protagonist will simply tank any hits and defeat the enemy usually in one or two big moves. It takes the bite out of the show when it tries to split it's focus between establishing the town and big arch villains waiting on the horizon. The overpowered nature does still come in useful in places, such as moments of diplomacy and particularly the teaching arc in the second half, but otherwise it drags things down quite a bit.


Artwork is good. The animation on Rimaru's slime form in particular is consistently expressive and genuinely appealing. Most of the designs are nice, though i'm not a particular fan of turning the races into just demi humans after a certain point but that's just anime for you. Very few flubs and moments where it didn't work for me, but there was also nothing particularly outstanding.


Sound is a similar level of quality. I do at least remember the OP which is nice but otherwise few tracks stick in my head and most of it is serviceable.


The characters are easily the best thing about this show. Sure these aren't the deepest and most complex characters ever, but they are entertaining and fun to watch interact off of one another and it's truly the moments where the show shines. And it's not all fun and games, dramatic moments and sad character revelations work nicely with how they're built up. The focus on diplomacy over fighting lends itself well to this notion so we can tend to find out about villains and characters without them just being killed off. Rimaru himself remains pretty entertaining as a protagonist and besides his overpowered nature, is a hoot to watch.


Despite my issues, it was hard not to have a blast watching this show. I wouldn't consider myself someone who's head over heels with isekai shows but this one definitely scratches a lot of my sweet spots for some more classic fantasy anime. It's not quite as mystical and original as all else, but it still presents something truly fun that I was looking forward to week after week.


Overall, this show's great. It only just falls short of being truly excellent for me and for some, I can imagine what I had hangups with won't detract from their enjoyment. It definitely keeps a good standard for this kind of show and I hope more anime in future takes notes. It might not be perfect, but it's worth looking at for future reference.


I couldn't think of any puns for this review so, splat.

This show starts off really strong. Which makes it all the more disappointing that it doesn't stay that way. First, the good. That Time I Got Reincarnated as a Slime sucks you in with the typical isekai fish-out-of-water beginning. The main character has to figure out what's going on, and the information unfolds out to the MC and to the viewer in a steady, enjoyable, drip. The animation also looks and sounds amazing.
Now, the bad. The show markets itself as a shonen action-style anime, when really it is slice of life. Everything always works out, Rimiru is overpowered, and there is zero tension. Which isfine, except the show asks us to take the fighting serious. The MC is a boring blank slate without any interesting qualities. Lastly, Rimiru does not face enough opposition, and gains many allies in cheap ways (that's the most spoiler-free way I can put it). I would recommend the show if you have nothing better to watch, but honestly it's nothing special.

When it comes to isekai series, a lot of people despise the common tropes, and to be honest, I get why. A lot of them are wish fulfillment power fantasies where we get to see the main character win over and over without ever facing real challenge. And here we have another one in that vein. And yet..... I don't hate it? It's not perfect, and I can totally see others despising it as another example of that trope, but personally, I think throwing it in that bucket and leaving it behind is a tad unfair for one main reason, this is not a showthat expects you to engage with it seriously. 


Now I'm not saying That Time I got Reincarnated as a Slime is a comedy. It has some great comedic moments here and there, but if you're here for laughs, you'll get a few, but nowhere near enough to keep you coming back. What I mean by it doesn't expect you to take it seriously is it's not a show about massive character arcs or hyped battles, it's a show about building your community, helping others, and trying to make your life and the life of others better. It's the sort of show you tune into to just feel relaxed and good, rather mindless entertainment. And while the fact that that's all its trying to be means I can't say its any sort of revolutionary show or masterpiece, there's a place for that sort of show in my heart. I'd almost call it fantasy slice of life, although with a few more sudden dangers to everything that probably weren't necessary. 


Part of why I think it works is the characters, while not that complex, are engaging enough and likable. Rimuru steals the show and really, if he wasn't such a fun character to watch, the show wouldn't work at all. What makes him fun is in his slime form, he's wonderfully expressive and bouncy, and when he gets a human form, he still has a sort of swagger and confidence, while at the same time being equally prone to expressions of "uhhhh, yeah, that was intentional.....". Which is also a good way to describe his personality. Since he is so powerful and has so many looking up to him, he tries to maintain an air of being in control, but being privy to his inner monologues, it's quite obvious that half the time, he's lying through his teeth or bluffing to high heaven. No, this doesn't make him complex or really that multifaceted, but it makes him fun to watch. And while they aren't as important or interesting, the other characters work well enough in their various tropes both playing them straight or subverting expectations. The only ones I found annoying were the female Oni who fought over Rimiru which I felt was probably the most extreme moment of wish fulfillment in the series. 


Speaking of, let's talk about that aspect. This show definitely leans into the power fantasy to a pretty good extent, and while it's less the adolescent fantasy of having power and women fawning over you while being dark and brooding and more the middle-aged fantasy of being perpetually able to help others and being important, it is still a power fantasy. It does enough for me to keep it from feeling pandering or like it's sacrificing character to allow anyone to slot themselves into the main character (actually, I'd argue of everything this show is, letting you self-insert really isn't one of them) but it is still a fantasy. And in terms of criticisms, most every time it tries for a more serious action arc, it's not particularly interesting. The series is not equipped to set up real stakes for Rimiru, so every time it starts leading to an action moment, it can be flashy, but ultimately hollow. And sadly, it really tries to push this in the latter half. The Charybdis arc is the worst example of this. 


Whether you enjoy this series or not really is going to be a question of what you want. If you're looking for a serious story or intricate characters, look elsewhere, you won't find it here. If you want something fun and not serious, you'll probably be satisfied enough. The biggest problem is the show repeatedly tries to put on the airs of being a grand epic when it really isn't. This is the "I've had a long day at work and want something to watch" show. Which has it's place, but that place is not standing as one of the greatest shows ever.

First time writing review here and instead of being a looong one ,i'll just get to the point without spoiling too much.
Starting few eps intrigued me but then it turned out just like another generic shounen shit show.
Characters came outta nowhere and the supporting characters development was not much. This show contains all sorts of cliche characters (the one who screams, the village idiot, the big tiddies girls..you name it, they're all there).
The only thing I like was the action fights , but the pacing felt a little off in the later episodes of the show.
So ultimalte story's concept was interesting but lacks in substance.
Honestly,I've only seen the anime and will not bother reading the manga after this.

*This is a Spoiler-less review with my summarized feeling at the end*
4X the anime
  I wanna preface this review by saying: isekai is not really my cup of tea, so keep that in mind when taking my opinion into account. Like every other isekai I watched, Slime only peaked my interest because of the hype surrounding it on the community. That said here’s what I think
  Slime has a strong start, moving very quickly and leaving very little time for boredom on the viewer. On the first 10 or so episodes we are introduced to a huge cast of characters, that althoughvery shallow in personality, work very well as comedic supports to our hero. The problem comes when the story never stops moving at this pace, so what was good to setup and bring the viewer into the world, starts to actively harm it. Old characters never get their due development, newer character’s gimmicks start to get very annoying (*cough* A certain demon lord girl *cough*) and arcs start and get solved in a matter of a couple of episodes. 

  The very light and fun premise of the show never becomes something more and by the end of it is not even that well executed anymore, at least in my opinion.


What I liked 

  Rimuru – Our protagonist is mostly interesting because of its approach of problems, always trying dialog first and forming alliances when possible. His upbeat nature is really captivating


 The animation – Mostly of this seasonal isekai are very poorly animated and just look to make a quick cash grab out of isekai fans. This show is not one of them. The animation quality and character design are both top notch and consistent throughout the whole show. 


What I have mixed feelings 

 The cast – while the initial cast is very fun, the jokes around the characters never change and become very stale the longer the show goes. The later introduced characters are less interesting at best and super annoying at worse 


What I disliked 

  Conflict solving – Everything comes very easy (this is not an understatement), there is very little tension in every possible SITUATION in this story. Literally every problem is solved with a very casual solution (that a lot of times just pops up) that while amusing and somewhat heartwarming at first gets old really fast. 


  The music – Very generic fantasy OST, nothing to write home about. The OP/EDs are all okay except the first OP which is at least a bit better


Watch this show if 

  - You want a very lighthearted isekai, where most of the fun is brought by the characters

  - You want to watch an OP (but not self-insert) protagonist solve problems by dialogue (well most of the times)

  - You want to watch a match of CIV with hacks 


Don’t watch this show if 

  - You don’t like isekai, this is not the show that will change your opinion

21/25 episodes in.
I would really like to give this anime a 10 however, it doesn't quite "deliver" enough for that.
One of the main reason is that towards the end, it seemed like they just put in pointless things that came out of nowhere.
But in the beginning of the series I actually really enjoyed it.
And the characters (especially rimuru) didn't really have any character development throughout the series.
While the art is great, I have indeed seen much better art in anime.
Sound-wise, the tracks were all kind of forgettable and lacking, but that doesn't really matter in my opinion.
Overall I give this anime an 8/10, because whileit was quite an enjoying experience it didn't quite meet my expectations. \n
But if you are someone who just wants to watch a generally fun anime and if you are an avid isekai fan, I would definitely recommend this anime for you.\n
The isekai genre as a whole has been getting a lot of slack but now with Tensei Slime and Shiled hero, I believe this is the real "birth" of the isekai genre.

The show has a surprisingly big heart and I would check it out if you like this type of show. I don't know ifyou don't because I don't know if it's strong enough to recommend to everyone. But it was doing well for itself in it's first half, so there's that.

So Let´s start with my first, ENGLISH review (Even tough up until now, I only reviewd in German):
First comes first: Even tough I shouldn´t comment on other comments, it seems that a few of them didn´t watch more than 2 Episodes. YES, he is OP (Just read the LN), his attitude was like that even before his death, so why change? It´s better that way. Than, getting to the first, big Crisis: He needed time to defeat his opponent. Second Crisis: He needed help because he wasn´t strong enough, so were is your so called "OP" element in that one? And we know, he isn´table to beat Milim, that will take A LOT of time until he IS able to. So there are at least 2 Characters which were more OP than Rimuru, he only looks strong because of the weaklings around him. And btw.: This is FICITION, Guys. Not the Real world. The fact of evolving after giving someone a Name is a great Idea. God, i hate it, when people looks 3 or 4 Episodes and try to let other think that they know everything they need.


Back to the Topic:


I´m very fond if the "Isekai Genre" because first: There aren´t many REAL Isekai Titles and second: revieving into another world sounds absolutely GLORIOUS. In this case, it might be a little bit oscure because of the fact that he revived as a slime. But the fact that you can´t bleed, can´t feeld pain and eat everything to learn about it or getting new Skills... it really Sounds Amazing. In fact, that´s the first Anime that made me buy the Manga-Version. Also: There aren´t many Animes with OP Characters like One Punch Man, so even tough Rimuru isn´t really OP but because of his, more or less, weaker companions, he looks like it. The fact that they stay by his side after evolving is something natural: eat or be eaten, literally. Monsters are simple: One joins one's patron, or even the "mightiest" in the forrest. In fact, if someone is able to get me stronger this instant like Rimuru only by evolving through giving other monsters a Name, i would stay by his side, too. Normal Logic, nothing more, nothing less. "Repaying the favor". It seems that even Monsters in Animes are more civilized than humans in the real world... :D The first Season is able to Impress, even with the Sound, i liked that sound of explosions and the Art of the most attacks. Even tough we were at the beginning of the Manga/LN/WN in this Anime, the Story was very good. I can REALLY recommend this Anime, but only if you watch it COMPLETELY and Understand it... not like a few others which seems to not Understand it :)

Well...
This ended up not living up to its full potential.
This anime is probably the best "modern isekai" or "reincarnation isekai" we have right now, but it has a problem - it has absolutely amazing first half that is pretty much on "masterpiece" level, and.... really disappointing second half, where things start going downhill. Really downhill. Stroeis and characters of the second half are no longer that interesting, story becomes dull, gritty/dark moments disappear, and even though the anime faitfhully portrays nearly everything that happened in manga during in first 12 episodes, in the next 12 episodes, it start.... rushing, skipping details (quite a lot ofthem), only to barely catch up with manga. I think they're preparing for the 2nd season.


And that is... disappointing.


Detailed breakdown below:


Story:6/10. It is 8/10 in 1st half, and 5/10 or 4/10 in the second. First 12 episodes are very interesting and are something I watched at the edge of my seat. The seond half of the season was very dull in comparison. It is partly fault of the source material, as the story arcs portrayed in first half of the season had more punch and higher quality overall.


Art: 6/10: Art is very good, especially in the beginning, before they start rushing the show. Things are animated with love, backgrounds are pretty, and animation si quite amazing, although they definitely cut some corners on action episodes. In he second half of the season, they start rushing, and quality goes down - there are more "panning" episodes, but it never becomes horrible.


Sound: 6/10: It is okay. Characters are likeable and voiced well, plus song isn't bad.


Character: 5/10: Well, to put it bluntly aside from amaizing secondary character in the first /second arc, majority of characters are quite dull, and they act more like story pieces or arton cutouts. Strictly defined role/personality, but little beyond that. No life-like personalities here.


Overall:" 6/10: I loved the 12 episodes, and slowly become disappointed in the show in the second half, as quality kept dropping down. It seems that this kind of development is fairly common among isekai mangas, where wrtier sometimes have cool ideas in the beginning, but once they've been played out doesn't really know what to do and can't create stories with the same kind of punch anymore. That's hte case with "Slime", I'm afraid. 


So the bottom line is - I'd recommend to watch 1st half of the season. It is really really really amazing. Can't say the same about the second half, though....

Let's be honest, getting reincarnated in a fantasy RPG world is a played out and severely overused theme in Anime.  It's completely uncreative at this point, yet, studios keep going back to the SAO well because it's hard to come up with fresh new ideas in anime and as long as something is popular among audiences, they're going to ride it until the wheels fall off.  
And so, we are introduced to yet another anime of this ilk in Tensura.  If you've seen any anime in this genre at all before, SAO, Log Horizon, Konosuba, etc... Then you've seen Tensura.  AndTensura brings all of the things that make those animes likable: Good action, a good comedy (Although Konosuba is far funnier) and an interesting and large crew.  


However, Tensura has made its crew too large, too quickly, and so most characters are kind of just "there".  Even ones with really good potential to be epic characters like the Ogres, Gobuta and Millim.  The crew is so big, that outside of a handful of characters, most don't get any significant lines to really build themselves up after their particular arcs are over.  It's kind of frustrating, because I really like a lot of these characters.  


The whole pace of the anime just moves too quickly for the viewer to become invested in anything as they should, so the anime feels like there's nothing at stake.  Especially since Rimuru is basically Saitama in terms of being OP.  Pretty much one move, three at most, and any threat is finished.   


This anime has a really good foundation, and the introduction of Kuro seems like Rimuru may finally have a real challenge, but going into future seasons, Tensura would benefit greatly from slowing the pace down and building up some emotional investment from arc to arc.  It would also benefit from giving more time to the cast that it continues to introduce and integrate into Rimuru's city.  Allow the viewer to get to know one group of characters for a while, before introducing more and pushing them to the back burner.  Characters like Benimaru, Souei, Millim and Gobuta could benefit from more screen time, before you introduce Chloe, Kuro and the Queen of Spirits.  


Still, Tensura is a fun anime to watch.  Smooth fight animations, some nice comedic moments, an entertaining cast, etc...  It's a not a bad anime at all.  It could just be better with more investment in the cast and introducing some kind of overarching serious threat that creates some kind of suspense in the anime.  As it stands now, no matter what Charbydis type create shows up, it'll be handled with ease and no sacrifice.  That drags the anime down.   


Hopefully it will improve going forward in these regards.

Most of the reviews are very positive or very negative.
